Lamothe (2016) states that: The U.S.-led coalition fighting against the Islamic State has prepared “all the pieces” it needs to take back the Iraqi city of Mosul, and expects military operations there are “rapidly approaching,” a senior State Department official said Friday.
Brett McGurk, the State Department’s envoy to the coalition, said the mission to take back the city of more than 1 million people will be “a very unpredictable, very dynamic, very uncertain operation.” It will be the most ambitious and complex operation the Iraqi government has undertaken against the Islamic State since it roared across the country in 2014, and include approximately 30,000 Iraqi forces.
McGurk, speaking at the State Department, said there’s a “humanitarian imperative” to expel the militants from Mosul as soon as possible. But he acknowledged putting the city back together will be a major undertaking. An extensive amount of planning has gone into understanding the political dynamics between different forces involved in the battle, the humanitarian assistance that will be required, and how local government will be organized after the battle, he said.
The remarks come after weeks of some U.S. and Iraqi officials questioning whether enough planning has been done to launch the battle, particularly in light of long-simmering political and religious tensions between groups that will be allied against the Islamic State in the operation. Concerns also remain that fighting in Mosul will provoke a sprawling humanitarian crisis with up to one million people internally displaced in Iraq.
McGurk acknowledged the concerns Friday, saying that while not all details of a transition after the battle have been finalized, the approach in place has worked “organically” in other Iraqi cities retaken from the Islamic State. He called the estimate that one million people will be displaced “apocalyptic” and unlikely to occur, and said land, supplies and accommodations will be ready for up to 750,000 people (para. 1-5). Economist (2016) The battle for Mosul states that: An imminent offensive hopes to end the jihadists’ reign of terror in Iraq’s second city. But the future is fraught with dangers Fear of a free-for-all Iraq has a plethora of other armed groups, able to draft in well over 100,000 men, who might improve the coalition’s odds substantially. But an influx of Kurdish or Shia militias risks not only alienating Mosul’s large Sunni Arab population but increasing the prospect that they might fight each other to determine the city’s post-IS order. Mr. Abadi seems sensibly intent on restricting the Kurds’ Peshmerga (“those who confront death”)and the Shias’ Hashd al-Shaabi (“popular mobilisation forces”) to laying a siege on the city’s outskirts. That would bring them financial benefits, since checkpoints are lucrative. And lest that prove insufficient, the government is also hoping to divert the Shia militias by having them launch an assault on two nearby towns under IS control, Hawijah and Tel Afar.
The Iraqi army’s preferred backups are two Sunni irregular forces. Sadly, both are fierce rivals. The first is led by Atheel al-Nujaifi, Mosul’s former governor, whose family has held sway in the city since Ottoman times. Based in Kurdistan, his 5,000 armed men work closely with the Peshmerga and are trained by the Turks. The second group comes from south of Mosul and is drawn largely from the Jabouri tribe. It works closely with Mr. Abadi’s lot and has contrived to replace Mr. Nujaifi as Mosul’s governor and his brother as parliament’s speaker with their own people, both Jabouris. Should outside forces pile in, a free-for-all could ensue, pitting Shias against Sunnis, Arabs against Kurds, and Iraqis against Turks (para. 8-9). Economist Website. (2016). The battle for Mosul. Reuters (2016) on September 20th stated that: Recent activities suggest Islamic State - also called Daesh in Arabic - will dig in, presaging a long and bloody fight that could displace large numbers of civilians. 
"Oil trenches, tunnels and suicide attacks will not save Daesh from defeat but they will make the battle more challenging," said Sabah al-Numani, a spokesman for the counter-terrorism forces which are expected to spearhead the offensive. "We are confident Daesh will fight to their last fighter to keep holding Mosul." 
There is a gap in the moat on the western approach to the city, so fighters could slip out through the desert and into Syria to regroup if they ultimately decide to surrender Mosul. 
Rich in Muslim history, Mosul lies at the heart of the state the Islamists have sought to create. It was in the city's main mosque in 2014 that their leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi declared a modern caliphate spanning large parts of Iraq and Syria. 
With much of the population still inside, civilians are a concern for those planning the expected assault. The installation of oil tanks around residential areas raises the risk that air strikes could set off major fires, said Baghdad-based analyst and former army general Jasim al-Bahadli. 
In addition to the moat, the militants have sealed off central districts of Mosul by stacking cement blast walls on top of each other across main roads, according to photographs taken by residents and seen by Reuters (para 7-11). Reuters. (2016). Islamic State digs in behind Mosul moat as battle for city looms. Today New.s World. Retrieved from
http://www.todayonline.com/world/islamic-state-digs-behind-mosul-moat-battle-city-looms?cx_tag=similartd&cid=tg:recos:similartd:standard#cxrecs_s Reuters (2016) on October 4 stated that: ISTANBUL - The United States and its allies must think carefully before launching an offensive to retake the Iraqi city of Mosul from Islamic State, Turkey's defense minister said on Tuesday, saying it could trigger an exodus of one million more refugees. 
Earlier on Tuesday, Turkish Prime Minister Binali Yildirim described plans for the expected assault on Iraq's second largest city as "not transparent", underscoring what appears to be growing concern from a NATO ally about the operation. 
Defense Minister Fikri Isik said any refugee flows out of Mosul, a city of more than two million people that has been in the hands of Islamic State since 2014, needed to be contained within Iraq's borders. 
"Our allies should weigh up very carefully the migration wave of about one million set to be caused by a possible Mosul operation," he said in a statement. 
"The migration should be absorbed in Iraq's territory. Otherwise it will impose a large burden on Turkey and that will affect Europe." 
Turkey is already home to more than 2.5 million refugees from the conflict in Syria, where Turkish forces are now engaged in an expanding operation in the north, backing rebel groups in their fight against Islamic State. 
Turkey is also using the operation to push back the Kurdish YPG militia, which it regards as a terrorist group and does not want encroaching on its territory. The YPG are supported by the United States (para. 1-7). Reuters. (2016). Offensive on Iraq's Mosul may produce a million migrants: Turkey. Today News World. Retrieved from
http://www.todayonline.com/world/turkish-defense-minister-warns-mosul-offensive-may-trigger-1-million-migrant-flood Reuters (2016) on September 9, stated that: TURNING TIDE 
Lieutenant General Vincent Stewart, Director of the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency, said on Thursday he expected the Mosul operation could unfold in the next two or three months but that it would be long and difficult. 
"Urban warfighting is not easy and this is a large city that has had at least two years to prepare to defend its position ... It's going to be a multi-dimensional fight," Stewart said at a national security summit in Washington. 
The war against jihadist insurgents in the Middle East has ebbed and flowed but there is a palpable sense in the region that the tide has turned against Islamic State. 
In the past year and a half, the group has lost swathes of territory and strategic outposts. In Iraq it was driven out of Tikrit and Sinjar in the north, the oil refinery town of Baiji, and finally Ramadi and Falluja in western Anbar province, the heart of the insurgency following the U.S.-led invasion in 2003 that toppled Saddam Hussein. 
In northern Syria, U.S.-allied Kurdish militia of the People's Protection Units (YPG) have taken vital territory and border crossings below the frontier with Turkey after capturing Kobani and later taking Tel Abyad, a key supply line for the jihadist capital Raqqa further south. The YPG has expanded its territory west of the Euphrates, seizing Manbij last month. 
Meanwhile Turkey, backing Syrian rebels, this month cleared Islamic State from its southern border by seizing some 20 villages while Libyan government forces are close to flushing IS insurgents from holdouts in Sirte (para.11-16). The fog of war (German: Nebel des Krieges) is the uncertainty in situational awareness experienced by participants in military operations. The term seeks to capture the uncertainty regarding one's own capability, adversary capability, and adversary intent during an engagement, operation, or campaign. Military forces try to reduce the fog of war through military intelligence and friendly force tracking systems. The term is also used to define uncertainty mechanics in wargames. Cruickshank and Dodwell (2016) state that: CTC: What are the challenges going to be with taking back Mosul and Raqqa from the Islamic State? Brennan: They’re dense urban environments. You look at Raqqa, much larger than that, a very dense urban environment. Mosul, over a million. Will ISIL leave or will they hunker down and fight? http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/29/world/middleeast/obama-troops-iraq.html As we've discussed previously, so as to circumvent limits on authorized troops, the Pentagon routinely employs the tactic of "basing" some thousands of troops offshore within the fleet, and rotating them in and out of country within some (30, 60, 90 day?) window so that their "official" status remains "temporary" and they are therefore not counted in official totals. As always, we are confronted with the discrepancy between the formal narrative and the informal (yet real) facts on the ground. Most people accept the formal number without thinking, and those that do know the truth accept the informal number with a wink and a nod. So, the statement that "there will soon be 5,000 American troops in Iraq" is false, for on any given day there are likely some number closer to 10,000. This is approximately the same number that the U.S. currently has garrisoned in Afghanistan, protecting the record-setting production of the poppie industry. Earlier today I watched an interview with CIA Director Brennan where he laments at the time ISIS has to plot and scheme to develop future attacks that they will deliver to the West. If ISIS is a serious threat, and they are, then the entire nonchalant approach to taking them out makes no sense. Why have they been allowed to continue? COMMENT:  I'm wondering how many of the 50k kits of personal protective gear have made their way to the Kurds, and I'm not sure that I believe (though I'd like to) Dorrian's assessment that ISIS morale in Mosul is flagging.   I am reminded of the reports from Vietnam;  everyone US or Vietnamese soldiers killed was, by definition, "VC".  In this instance,  how do we know that everyone killed by Iraqi, rebel or coalition forces are "ISIS"?  And how do we know who was in those 29 boats or vehicles attempting to escape Mosul?   I'm no military historian, but it seems to me that military-types always tell the story in a way to make themselves seem victorious, when the reality could be quite the opposite:  maybe all those people were innocent civilians.  What hard facts do we really have about the forces in Mosul, and their morale?   This is one of those questions in which there are unknowns of all sorts:  known, unknown, and assumed--both correctly and incorrectly.   It seems to me that when there's a lot of unknowns, there is a great potential for things to not go as planned--both for the better and for the worse.  It's possible Mosul will fall in short order, OR become a very long bloody battle. The later the offensive is launched, the less likely that this question will resolve as "yes" because there would be insufficient time for even the best-case scenario. But I wish I had bought a crystal ball when they were on sale at Walmart!

By GORDON LUBOLD and  PAUL SONNE
Updated Sept. 22, 2016 12:27 a.m. ET
44 COMMENTS
WASHINGTON—The U.S. military is requesting authority to send up to 500 new troops to Iraq ahead of a much-anticipated campaign to take back Mosul from Islamic State, according to U.S. officials, adding to an expanding American presence in the country. The new deployment, if approved by the White House, would assist Iraqi and coalition forces in preparing for the battle to capture the northern city, the extremist group’s last major stronghold in Iraq. That fight is expected to begin as early as mid-October, U.S. officials have said.   The U.S. move would come in the wake of an operation that began Tuesday by Iraqi forces in Shirqat, a town north of Baghdad, to further degrade Islamic State supply lines into Mosul. That operation, which was announced by Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi in New York, where he is participating in U.N. General Assembly meetings, is a further indication that the Iraqi forces are preparing for the larger fight in Mosul, a city of about one million people. The new U.S. forces would increase the number of American personnel officially deployed to Iraq from 4,400 to about 4,900. The Pentagon also maintains up to 1,500 additional U.S. forces that it doesn’t acknowledge as part of its Iraq force, most at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad or on temporary assignments. The new deployment would bring the overall U.S. presence to as high as 6,400. The 500 would be in addition to roughly 400 new personnel the U.S. sent to Iraq in early September to prepare for the Mosul offensive. President Barack Obama hasn’t yet been presented with the military plan, according to U.S. officials. The White House maintains that the troops the Pentagon sends to Iraq aren’t heading into direct combat. Rather, U.S. officials have said, those troops are there in an advise-and-assist mission. While they are armed and always have the authority to defend themselves on the battlefield, they aren’t performing direct action missions, officials have said repeatedly. Advise-and-assist forces operate under instructions to remain “one terrain feature” behind any battle, meaning they must stay some distance behind the front lines of fighting and serve only in an advisory role. However, there have been instances in which U.S. troops have been killed or injured while operating under these strict guidelines. Most of the new troops would be assigned to an area the U.S. military has established south of Mosul at a logistics hub known as “Q-West” near the city of Qayara. Hundreds of U.S. and coalition forces have massed there in the past several months in anticipation of the Mosul fight. The same base was the target this week of what U.S. officials said was a rocket or mortar fired by Islamic State fighters, and containing a mustard agent, into the perimeter of the base where U.S. service members are deployed, senior defense officials confirmed Wednesday. The weapon was described as “crude” and ineffective. No U.S. personnel were injured in the Tuesday attack. But the incident marked the first time Islamic State had deployed a weapon containing a mustard agent against U.S. forces, defense officials said. The attack resulted in no change in security posture, defense officials said. Islamic State has used weapons with a mustard agent about two dozen times. They typically have been used against Iraqi or Peshmerga forces or Iraqi civilians, officials said. The fight for Mosul—seen as the biggest battle yet against Islamic State—has been delayed for more than a year. The U.S. military has hinted at different times the effort would begin. Mr. Abadi recently has signaled he wants the city taken by the end of the year. In recent months, U.S. officials also have said that the Iraqi military appears ready to take the lead in the fight and as recently as two weeks ago said they expected Iraqi and coalition forces to enter the city sometime in October. U.S. military officials have said it is unclear what kind of fight they will find once inside Mosul. Gen. Joe Votel, who heads U.S. Central Command, said last month there may be areas Islamic State decides to cede to coalition forces immediately, and others in which it decides to fight to the death. “They are going to have to make hard decisions about where they’re going to concentrate their power and where they’re going to have to let the coalition and our indigenous partners succeed, and that’s kind of what I see going forward,” Gen. Votel said at the Pentagon on Aug. 30. Separately, the White House is considering steps in Syria to more directly arm the Kurdish forces it has been supporting there. That decision would help to focus the so-called YPG, which may be the primary force behind the retaking of the Islamic State stronghold of Raqqa, the de facto capital of the militant group’s caliphate. U.S. officials have been discussing ways to help prepare the YPG for that fight, and the YPG has sought more direct assistance from Washington in the form of more small arms, ammunition and possibly some non-lethal assistance like trucks or medical equipment. Up until now, the U.S. has only indirectly armed Kurdish forces, seen as the most effective in the fight against Islamic State, by equipping the Syrian Democratic Forces, which include Arabs who are closely aligned with Kurdish forces. The U.S. has provided numerous ammunition drops to the SDF as a fig leaf for its quieter support of the Kurds there, U.S. officials have said. The move likely would anger Turkey, which believes the Kurds seek a semi-autonomous state along its border inside Syria and equates military assistance to the YPG with helping the Kurds take a step closer to that end".

The new U.S. forces would increase the number of American personnel officially deployed to Iraq from 4,400 to about 4,900. The Pentagon also maintains up to 1,500 additional U.S. forces that it doesn’t acknowledge as part of its Iraq force, most at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad or on temporary assignments. The new deployment would bring the overall U.S. presence to as high as 6,400. The 500 would be in addition to roughly 400 new personnel the U.S. sent to Iraq in early September to prepare for the Mosul offensive. President Barack Obama hasn’t yet been presented with the military plan, according to U.S. officials. The White House maintains that the troops the Pentagon sends to Iraq aren’t heading into direct combat. Rather, U.S. officials have said, those troops are there in an advise-and-assist mission. While they are armed and always have the authority to defend themselves on the battlefield, they aren’t performing direct action missions, officials have said repeatedly. Advise-and-assist forces operate under instructions to remain “one terrain feature” behind any battle, meaning they must stay some distance behind the front lines of fighting and serve only in an advisory role. However, there have been instances in which U.S. troops have been killed or injured while operating under these strict guidelines. Most of the new troops would be assigned to an area the U.S. military has established south of Mosul at a logistics hub known as “Q-West” near the city of Qayara. Hundreds of U.S. and coalition forces have massed there in the past several months in anticipation of the Mosul fight. The same base was the target this week of what U.S. officials said was a rocket or mortar fired by Islamic State fighters, and containing a mustard agent, into the perimeter of the base where U.S. service members are deployed, senior defense officials confirmed Wednesday. The weapon was described as “crude” and ineffective. No U.S. personnel were injured in the Tuesday attack. But the incident marked the first time Islamic State had deployed a weapon containing a mustard agent against U.S. forces, defense officials said. The attack resulted in no change in security posture, defense officials said. Islamic State has used weapons with a mustard agent about two dozen times. They typically have been used against Iraqi or Peshmerga forces or Iraqi civilians, officials said. The fight for Mosul—seen as the biggest battle yet against Islamic State—has been delayed for more than a year. The U.S. military has hinted at different times the effort would begin. Mr. Abadi recently has signaled he wants the city taken by the end of the year. In recent months, U.S. officials also have said that the Iraqi military appears ready to take the lead in the fight and as recently as two weeks ago said they expected Iraqi and coalition forces to enter the city sometime in October. U.S. military officials have said it is unclear what kind of fight they will find once inside Mosul. Gen. Joe Votel, who heads U.S. Central Command, said last month there may be areas Islamic State decides to cede to coalition forces immediately, and others in which it decides to fight to the death. “They are going to have to make hard decisions about where they’re going to concentrate their power and where they’re going to have to let the coalition and our indigenous partners succeed, and that’s kind of what I see going forward,” Gen. Votel said at the Pentagon on Aug. 30. Separately, the White House is considering steps in Syria to more directly arm the Kurdish forces it has been supporting there. That decision would help to focus the so-called YPG, which may be the primary force behind the retaking of the Islamic State stronghold of Raqqa, the de facto capital of the militant group’s caliphate. U.S. officials have been discussing ways to help prepare the YPG for that fight, and the YPG has sought more direct assistance from Washington in the form of more small arms, ammunition and possibly some non-lethal assistance like trucks or medical equipment. Up until now, the U.S. has only indirectly armed Kurdish forces, seen as the most effective in the fight against Islamic State, by equipping the Syrian Democratic Forces, which include Arabs who are closely aligned with Kurdish forces. The U.S. has provided numerous ammunition drops to the SDF as a fig leaf for its quieter support of the Kurds there, U.S. officials have said. The move likely would anger Turkey, which believes the Kurds seek a semi-autonomous state along its border inside Syria and equates military assistance to the YPG with helping the Kurds take a step closer to that end". Major fracture in Kurdistan Alliance and cooperation between Erbil & Baghdad (Baghdad is depending on Erbil's cooperation for Mosul): By Emily Anagnostos and the ISW Iraq Team The Iraqi Council of Representatives (CoR) voted out Kurdish Finance Minister Hoshyar Zebari in a vote of no-confidence rendered by simple majority on September 21. The vote was held by a secret ballot in a vote of 158 to 77. The Iraqi Constitution (Article 61.8.A) mandates that a minister be dismissed on the basis of an absolute majority, which is 165 CoR members.The vote was rendered therefore in a simple majority, the same method that the CoR dismissed Defense Minister Khalid al-Obeidi on August 25.CoR Speaker Salim al-Juburi denied a request from 102 CoR members for re-vote on whether to proceed from the questioning session, held on August 25, to a vote of no-confidence. Juburi also denied a request from Prime Minister Haidar al-Abadi to postpone the no-confidence vote. PM Abadi argued that Zebari is critical to Iraq's ongoing negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) regarding major international loan agreements. Juburi likewise denied a request from 50 CoR members to postpone the vote.

The Kurdistan Alliance has effectively collapsed, due intra-Kurdish tensions in the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) that spilled into politics in Baghdad. Kurdish political parties have varying interests in Arbil, but they have historically agreed to present a unified platform in Baghdad in order to exact concession for the KRG. However, tensions between Zebari's party, the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), and a Kurdish opposition party, Gorran, in the KRG have escalated and now affect politics in Baghdad. The Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) has split loyalties in the dispute, and this internal fracture has failed to prevent the vote from succeeding. Early reports suggest that most non-KDP Kurdish CoR members voted to dismiss Zebari, likely in order to punish the KDP. The KDP issued a statement calling the dismissal a "violation of the Constitution and the law." The fracture of the Kurdistan Alliance will deprive all Kurdish parties their ability to influence politics in the Iraqi Government.

Former Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki's shadow party, the Reform Front, spearheaded the vote, as it did for Defense Minister Khalid al-Obeidi. Maliki hit on fault lines in the Kurdistan Alliance in order to benefit his own interests. Maliki is seeking allies that can support a bid for the premiership and has repeatedly courted the PUK and Gorran to join his support base. He is also targeting ministers who are key allies for PM Abadi in an effort to undermine Abadi's premiership.

ISW has previously assessed the implications of Zebari's dismissal. These include:

Zebari dismissal could compromise ongoing financial negotiations that are critical for Iraq's economic stability. This includes ongoing discussions with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which are scheduled to resume in Washington, D.C., in early October. Zebari has been instrumental for obtaining the $5.3 billion standby loan. His absence may prevent Iraq from unlocking greater loan amounts and addressing Iraq's overall financial crisis.
The U.S. campaign for Mosul could suffer if the KDP and Baghdad, two of the U.S.'s major ground partners, no longer have an effective relationship. The breakdown of relations between the KDP and the Iraqi Government may complicate the current plan and timeline for Mosul. The majority of anti-ISIS operations in northern Iraq have occurred in KDP-governed terrain and alongside KDP-Peshmerga, who will be the primarily Peshmerga force to participate in Mosul operations, which are intended to launch in the upcoming months. The KDP made "historic" agreements with Baghdad on September 19 over coordination and force composition in the Mosul operations. If the KDP rejects the oversight of the federal government, or if the U.S.'s ability to work with the KDP is hampered by poor Baghdad-Arbil relations, the timeline or success of the Mosul operations may suffer. The KDP may also use poor relations with Baghdad to rebuff plans for the post-ISIS administration of Mosul that do not include Kurdish governance. The KDP may also push to expand Kurdish territory outside of the KRG's boundaries.
Maliki and the Reform Front may ultimate target PM Abadi with a no-confidence vote. Maliki and the Reform Front has now successfully engineered the unconstitutional removal of two ministers, putting the survival of any minister in the Iraqi Government at stake. Zebari and Defense Minister Obeidi were two of PM Abadi's important allies in the Iraqi Government. Maliki's ability to remove PM Abadi's allies and gain support for himself could prompt a call for a dismissal of PM Abadi. Without the support of the Kurdish and Sunni parties, PM Abadi may have insufficient support to ensure he survives the vote.
The split between the Kurdish parties jeopardizes a push for Kurdish independence because an independence referendum would require the support of all Kurdish parties. An independent Iraqi Kurdistan without the PUK-governed territories - primarily the oil-rich Kirkuk Province - is not financially viable. The PUK, which controls half of the Kurdish territories, may block attempts by the KDP to declare independence because the move would be spearheaded by KRG President Masoud Barzani and the KDP. Kurdish independence is less likely, though Barzani will escalate calls for a referendum. However the KDP could still withdraw from Iraqi Government. This will further remove an obstacle for Maliki to gain overarching influence in the CoR and move to retake the premiership

CNN)US forces will be ready within weeks to help Iraqi forces in their battle to retake Mosul from ISIS, according to Gen. Joseph Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. "Our job is to actually help the Iraqis generate the forces and the support necessary for operations in Mosul and we'll be ready for that in October," Dunford told a small group of reporters traveling with him.
"The noose is gradually tightening around Mosul," he added.
The city, Iraq's second-largest, is ISIS' last significant stronghold in the country. It and Syria's Raqqa -- the group's self-declared capital -- are the major targets left for the US-led coalition to take back from its control.
Dunford's statement is the clearest sign from a senior US military official that the military battle for Mosul could soon begin once the Iraqis make the political decision to proceed. It also means the battle for Mosul may be raging during the US presidential election, with US forces facing dangers on the battlefield. Those troops might also be called upon to help begin providing humanitarian aid.
Dunford, along with Defense Secretary Ash Carter, is scheduled to testify before the Senate Armed Services Committee Thursday. Both are expected to face stiff questioning from Republicans on the panel about the Obama administration's strategy to fight ISIS.
CNN has learned the Pentagon is now considering setting up new remote bases well outside Mosul as hubs from which US forces can operate.
Those types of bases, given their locations, are likely to be less secure than the large bases the US has generally been using. They could be used by US military advisers who are expected to work with the Iraqis in the field.
Because of the remote locations, security may be difficult. US forces may move "in and out" of the bases rather than locate there consistently, one official said. These bases are in addition to the large Iraqi base south of Mosul at Qayyarah, where hundreds of US troops are already located to assist with supplies, logistics and support for the Iraqi forces.
A key decision to be made is whether additional US conventional and special operations forces will be needed for ensuring the Iraqis succeed, several US defense official told CNN. The US forces will not be on the front lines but will be out in the field with Iraqi units, officials said.
Some forces already in Iraq could be reassigned to northern Iraq, or additional forces could be sent.
President Barack Obama and Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's meeting in New York Monday also signaled the Mosul operation may soon unfold.
"We feel confident that we will be in a position to move forward fairly rapidly," Obama said. Calling Mosul a "challenging battle," Obama also noted that the US will be "prepared to help provide rapid humanitarian assistance" to displaced Iraqis.
Abadi underscored the urgency.
"We hope within the next few months we're going to kick Daesh out of Mosul and we'll deliver a huge blow to what Daesh believes in," said Abadi, using another name for the terrorist group" http://edition.cnn.com/2016/09/20/politics/iraq-mosul-isis/index.html

Through sandbags on the eastern front of Bashiq, one can see the urban sprawl of Mosul – a metropolis once home to 2.5 million people – 15km away. A two- to three-kilometre stretch of no-man's land, which separates the Kurdish forces and Islamic State lines, is increasingly being crossed by civilians at night, many of them desperate, hungry and in fear of their lives. As many as a million people are expected to make a similar journey from Mosul in the coming months. One night last month, up to 200 civilians made their escape to one outlying post alone. Shortage of food Peshmerga general Mohammad Rasool, who received the escapees at his post 2km from Islamic State lines, tells The Irish Times that, according to those escaping, Mosul was short of food and civilians were eating only one meal a day. In Mosul, they say, a bag of flour costs 50,000 Iraqi dinars ($43/€38). A cylinder of gas costs $50 while in Irbil, the Kurdish capital, it costs $4. Gen Rasool, in common with his commanding officers on the Bashiq frontline, is awaiting orders to attack Mosul. "The Mosul attack . . . won't be as difficult as thought [because] Isis is not as strong as before," he says. Salaries paid to Islamic State fighters have been reduced from thousands of dollars a month to a few hundred, he adds, and many fighters have quit "because they were with Isis for money". Foreign fighters, among Islamic State's best, have already left Mosul, and he expects the people of the city to rise up once the fighting begins. Gen Rasool claims the Mosul operation could be "over in one month" if the United States and coalition forces provide more modern weaponry to the Kurds. His men are equipped with Soviet-era Kalashnikovs. Brig Gen Bahram Yassin, overall commander of the Kurdish Peshmerga forces on the Bashiq frontline, believes there are 20,000 Islamic State fighters in Mosul but he expects the city to be cleared of Isis before the end of the year. He says the civilians who have made it to the Bashiq front line are traumatised from life under Isis. "The people we received – children, women and the elderly – are in poor psychological condition" because they witnessed daily arrests and executions. There is no food in Mosul, no work and no services. Dark ages "Isis wants to put the people back into the dark ages," says Brig Gen Yassin. "They are against freedom, democracy and development and they are against co-existence. Either you will be with Isis and their ideology or you will be killed, [so] you must run away. That's why it is a very dangerous ideology. "The Peshmerga are fighting on behalf of all of the world. That's why we are waiting for the world's help to defeat Isis," he adds,"

IS 'scorched earth' tactics and resulting damage to infrastructure may push back October H-hour. Adjusting down 10 basis points.
Stratfor, September 16, 'Tracing the Islamic State's Path of Destruction': https://www.stratfor.com/analysis/tracing-islamic-states-path-destruction?utm_source=LinkedIn&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=article
Clips from Stratfor article:
"An Iraqi air base critical to the impending offensive against Islamic State forces in Mosul may be too damaged to fully function. In June 2014, the jihadist group overran Qayyarah air base and the village surrounding it, which lie just 60 kilometers (37 miles) south of Mosul. Though Iraqi troops retook the base July 9 after launching a protracted ground attack from Baghdad, satellite imagery taken Sept. 13 shows the tremendous damage that Islamic State fighters managed to inflict on the base's facilities before they were forced to retreat. By employing scorched earth tactics at one of the bases used to support the coming operation against Mosul, the group likely hoped to slow the coalition advancing on its positions in and around the city. Nevertheless, it is unlikely that the operation to retake Mosul will begin in October as originally planned. Beyond restoring Qayyarah air base's facilities and capabilities, the anti-Islamic State coalition still needs to concentrate a sizable force near Mosul. But debates on the use of largely Shiite popular mobilization units and Turkey's role in the fight have stalled preparations for the offensive, in all likelihood pushing it to the end of the year. In the meantime, officials in Baghdad will have to contend with the fact that the air base was not the only part of Qayyarah to be demolished; the Islamic State also torched the village's oil fields. They are by no means the largest oil fields in Iraq, and their temporary loss will not deal a significant blow to Baghdad's revenue. Coupled with the damage to the air base, though, it could be a chilling sign of what lies in store for Iraq: As the Islamic State loses ground, it is making a concerted effort to ensure that its opponents cannot use the land or resources it leaves behind." http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/13/politics/pentagon-mulls-more-troops-isis-iraq-syria/ Here's an article that just throws one gigantic mudball, full of a dozen critical factors, up into the air and says: "Sort it out yourself!" Well, I've been looking for information on the operational status of the Qayyarah airbase ("Improvements at a nearby Iraqi airbase at Qayyarah are wrapping up"), so that seems positive. Also, however, there is a new signal as to some delay in the overall timetable ("the Iraqis may not be fully ready to move until early November"), which seems negative. There is also the headlined issue of more troops, as well as the changing nature of the role of such troops, plus more. Sorting and sifting gives me a +1 (primarily because my confidence that a "determined" assault on Mosul will begin in the period, and that, so far, my estimate of six weeks from assault to retaking still, although barely, falls within 2016.) Coalition planes destroy ISIS chemical factory near Mosul
http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/217749 To my mind the proffered reason that this facility was bombed out of existence ("the production center ...  likely made chlorine or mustard gas") is so tenuous that, if we only take a few moments to stop and think about it, *everything* gets called into question. The production of chlorine gas, if ISIS is so committed, is so easy that an industrial facility is not required for the purpose. Yet, an industrial facility is just that, something that provides industrial efficiencies at scale.  So, what's really going on here is that some industrial facility which likely provided feedstocks to some innumerable number of applications, from sanitation to fertilizers to paints, whatever, you name it, has been destroyed. In short, there's something else going on in Iraq: it's industrial infrastructure is being eliminated. The role of the U.S. rocket artillery, and the recently announced French ground artillery, are along the same lines. These are not tactics necessary for the defeat of ISIS jihadist fighters. These are tactics employed to destroy the industrial base of the surviving inhabitants of that land. These are tactics that evidence a desire to place future inhabitants into a position of dependence. These tactics have nothing to do with fighting ISIS. We are conversant with the colloquial term "over-kill." We think we know what that means. Think of the concept of "over-destruction." Now add the difference in motivation from blood lust, or whatever you think could apply to a condition of over-kill, and think of various motives for over-destruction. Some set of these are at play.  As a public, we are so far out of the loop on the *true* objectives in Iraq that it's amazing we feel confident enough to offer any opinion on the timeline for the Mosul venture at all. Stupid humans we are (myself included). How to produce Chlorine Gas
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AaJc09SCTpQ This is obviously a hobby video, but the point is that sufficient quantities of chlorine gas could be produced, if ISIS were so determined, without industrial scale equipment. The incident was one of overdestruction for a non-stated reason.

A forecaster I respect has been saying for months that Mosul will be retaken as fast as it initially fell, and in about the same way, i.e. ISIS will abandon it.  It has occurred to me recently that people engaged in a holy war are more willing to endure a military defeat to anything that might look  like they lost their faith:  martyrdom is preferable to appearing weak, cowardly, or of insufficient faith.  Martyrdom is a victory in a holy war. Therefore, because for ISIS, this is a holy war,  I do  not think ISIS will abandon Mosul. In other words, the fight will be messy, bloody and long.   As to when it may begin in ernest, who will participate, and how Mosul will be governed afterwards, I'm not sure.  I read conflicting reports:  that all is settled about how Mosul will be governed afterwards and who will participate in the retaking of it, and that nothing is settled.  I read that the Kurds are getting annoyed with repeated delays and are eager to begin the main assault, and that the Kurds don't want to govern Mosul, but that they have agreed to.  There's similarly conflicting reports about the readiness of the Iraqis and the participation of Shiite militias.  This lack of clarity leads me to think that the battle will be similarly confused and disorganized, which I think bodes ill for a swift conclusion.

Maintaining my forecast for now. Recent reports are that troops are massing (up to 30,000) and that they are cutting off the city from outside access.  The US has sent more advisers. The Institute for the Study of War (ISW) and the Critical Threats Project (CTP) at the American Enterprise Institute conducted an intensive multi-week planning exercise to frame, design, and evaluate potential courses of action that the United States could pursue to defeat the threat from the Islamic State in Iraq and al Sham (ISIS) and al Qaeda in Iraq and Syria. ISW and CTP will publish the findings of this exercise in multiple reports. The first report examined America’s global grand strategic objectives as they relate to the threat from ISIS and al Qaeda.[1] This second report defines American strategic objectives in Iraq and Syria, identify the minimum necessary conditions for ending the conflicts there, and compare U.S. objectives with those of Iran, Russia, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia in order to understand actual convergences and divergences. The differences mean that the U.S. cannot rely heavily on international partners to achieve its objectives. Subsequent reports will provide a detailed assessment of the situation on the ground in Syria and present the planning group’s evaluation of several courses of action. The key findings of this second report are: The U.S. must accomplish four strategic objectives in Iraq and Syria to achieve vital national interests and secure its people: 1) destroy enemy groups; 2) end the communal, sectarian civil wars; 3) set conditions to prevent the reconstitution of enemy groups; and 4) extricate Iraq and Syria from regional and global conflicts.
Any American strategy must take urgent measures to strengthen Iraqi Prime Minister Abadi and prepare contingency efforts for his fall. The collapse of the Abadi government and return of his predecessor Nuri al Maliki would be disastrous for the fight against ISIS.
Ongoing international negotiations within the Vienna Framework are bypassing essential requirements for long-term success in Syria. Re-establishing a stable, unitary Syrian state that secures American interests requires the U.S. and its partners to 1) destroy ISIS, Jabhat al Nusra, and foreign Salafi-jihadi groups in Syria; 2) identify and strengthen interlocutors representing the Syrian opposition; 3) facilitate a negotiated settlement between the Syrian regime and opposition; 4) obtain regional acceptance of that settlement; 5) establish peace-enforcement mechanisms; and 6) reconstruct state institutions.
The Salafi-jihadi militant base in Syria poses a threat to the U.S., but the U.S. must not simply attack it because that would put the U.S. at war with many Sunnis who must be incorporated into a future, post-Assad inclusive government. The U.S. must separate reconcilable from irreconcilable elements. These other Salafi-jihadi groups must meet the following conditions essential for core U.S. security objectives in order to participate: break with Jabhat al Nusra and ISIS; accept the principle of a future pluralistic and unitary Syrian state; reject violent jihad; commit to disarming to a policing and defensive level; and commit to the elimination of the current shari’a court system and the establishment of political institution-based governance.
The superficial convergence of Iranian, Russian, Turkish, and Saudi strategic objectives with those of the U.S. on ISIS as a threat masks significant divergences that will undermine U.S. security requirements. Iran and Russia both seek to reduce and eliminate U.S. influence in the Middle East and are not pursuing strategies that will ultimately defeat al Qaeda and ISIS in Syria or Iraq. Turkey’s support for the Muslim Brotherhood and other Islamist groups, some linked to al Qaeda, stem from the ruling party’s intent to reestablish itself as an independent, Muslim, regional power. Finally, Saudi Arabia’s objectives remain shaped by perceived existential threats from Iran and a growing succession crisis, causing key divergences, especially over support to Salafi-jihadi groups. The U.S. must lead efforts to resolve the crisis in Syria and cannot outsource them to partners." In short, as there is no agreement between US and its coalition partners about a future for Iraq or Mosul, there can be no final assault unless Shiite miltias out of the picture. http://understandingwar.org/backgrounder/new-report-series-us-grand-strategy-destroying-isis-and-al-qaeda-0

Mar 14, 2016 - John Lawrence The Institute for the Study of War (ISW) and the Critical Threats Project (CTP) at the American Enterprise Institute conducted an intensive multi-week planning exercise to frame, design, and evaluate potential courses of action that the United States could pursue to destroy the Islamic State of Iraq and al Sham (ISIS) and al Qaeda in Iraq and Syria. ISW and CTP are publishing the findings of this exercise in multiple reports in a series titled U.S Grand Strategy: Destroying ISIS and al Qaeda. The first report – Al Qaeda and ISIS: Existential Threats to the U.S. and Europe -- describes America’s global grand strategic objectives as they relate to the threat from ISIS and al Qaeda. The second – Competing Visions for Syria and Iraq:  The Myth of an Anti-ISIS Grand Coalition -- defines American strategic objectives in Iraq and Syria, identifies the minimum necessary conditions for ending the conflicts there, and compares U.S. objectives with those of Iran, Russia, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia in order to understand actual convergences and divergences. The third report -- Jabhat al Nusra and ISIS:  Sources of Strength -- assesses the strengths and vulnerabilities of ISIS and al Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al Nusra to serve as the basis for developing a robust and comprehensive strategy to destroy them. Subsequent reports will provide a detailed assessment of the situation on the ground in Syria and present the planning group’s evaluation of several courses of action. http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/7-isis-members-killed-booby-trap-cars-lab-destroyed-in-tal-afar/ The entire strategic orientation to the western approaches of Mosul confuses me. At present, it appears these approaches to Mosul are open, thus allowing inter-communication with ISIS elements in Syria and elsewhere (Mosul is not fully encircled); and that there are no plans, even after some direct assault upon Mosul might begin, to close these approaches. As stated previously, leaving an escape route is a common tactic in siege campaigns, but usually only after some period of full encirclement. In addition, the reports as to what is occurring in the region are strange. Some indicate it is spotted with Kurdish positions, while other reports indicate Tal Afar is a Shiite populated village, and yet it is a contested area with no semblance of coalition control. Even the particular report cited above is confusing. I can't interpret the word "lab" in the sense of a location that is conducting original car-bombing research (despite the fact that such dedicated research facilities are known to exist). Instead, I am interpreting this to mean some sort of construction or assembly facility. And, if this is true, why would ISIS place a "booby-trap car [assembly facility]" in such an out-of-the-way, isolated area? Why drive a bomb-laden car 50-100 km to get to the target? Maybe it was a bomb-maker training facility, and not so much a lab. In any case, I'm continuing with my "any action in the Tal Afar vicinity is good action" heuristic, but recognize it as a very sloppy tool. Late half-measures better than none?

A lot of forecasters have provided many good links about the Iraqi government's plans for an impending offensive against Mosul; I don't dispute the veracity of any of these stories, nor do I think that the Iraqi government is insincere about its intentions or deliberately misleading anyone about its proposed timetable.  However, according to every article I've seen, any plan to retake Mosul relies heavily on the cooperation of the Peshmerga. Given the unsettled situation with the Turkish intervention in Syria, and the likelihood that the Kurds are the ultimate target of the Turkish military, I consider it improbable that the Kurds would commit their military forces to an offensive against a secondary military opponent like ISIS when those forces may be needed to face the existential threat of the Turks. The Kurds are only concerned with the survival of Kurdistan, and to them, the border between "Iraqi Kurdistan" and "Syrian Kurdistan" does not exist. It seems to me that the Kurds will be very hesitant to undertake major operations in Iraq when the troops committed to those operations might be needed to reinforce the Kurdish cantons in Syria. It's worth noting that a major diversion of Kurdish forces in Iraq might even tempt the Turks to take advantage of the distraction to strike Kurdish areas in Syria.

2nd Battle of Fallujah (from one of my earlier posts): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Fallujah
Date: 7 November – 23 December 2004
(1 month, 2 weeks and 2 days)
Coalition Forces:
U.S., Iraqi and British forces totaled about 13,500. The U.S. had gathered some 6,500 Marines and 1,500 Army soldiers that would take part in the assault with about 2,500 Navy personnel in support roles. U.S. troops were grouped in two Regimental Combat Teams: Regimental Combat Team 1 comprised 3rd Battalion/1st Marines, 3rd Battalion/5th Marines, Naval Mobile Construction Battalion 4 and 23 (Seabees) as well as the U.S. Army's 2nd Battalion/7th Cavalry. Regimental Combat Team 7 comprised the 1st Battalion/8th Marines, 1st Battalion/3rd Marines, the U.S. Army's 2nd Battalion/2nd Infantry and 2nd Battalion/12th Cavalry. About 2,000 Iraqi troops assisted with the assault. All were supported by aircraft and U.S. Marine and U.S. Army artillery battalions.
The 850-strong 1st Battalion of the Black Watch was ordered to help U.S. and Iraqi forces with the encirclement of Fallujah. As part of Task Force Black, D Squadron of the British SAS prepared to take part in the operation, but due to British political nervousness about the possible scale of the slaughter stopped any direct UK involvement in the ground battle.
Insurgent Forces:
In April, Fallujah was defended by about 500 "hardcore" and 1,000+ "part time" insurgents. By November, it was estimated that the numbers had doubled. Another estimate put the number of insurgents at 3,000; however, a number of insurgent leaders escaped before the attack.
The Iraqi insurgents and foreign mujahadeen present in the city prepared fortified defenses in advance of the anticipated attack. They dug tunnels, trenches, prepared spider holes, and built and hid a wide variety of IEDs. In some locations they filled the interiors of darkened homes with large numbers of propane bottles, large drums of gasoline, and ordnance, all wired to a remote trigger that could be set off by an insurgent when troops entered the building. They blocked streets with Jersey barriers and even emplaced them within homes to create strong points behind which they could attack unsuspecting troops entering the building. Insurgents were equipped with a variety of advanced small arms, and had captured a variety of U.S. armament, including M14s, M16s, body armor, uniforms and helmets.
They booby-trapped buildings and vehicles, including wiring doors and windows to grenades and other ordnance. Anticipating U.S. tactics to seize the roof of high buildings, they bricked up stairwells to the roofs of many buildings, creating paths into prepared fields of fire which they hoped the troops would enter.
Intelligence briefings given prior to battle reported that coalition forces would encounter Chechen, Filipino, Saudi, Libyan, and Syrian combatants, as well as native Iraqis.

Eyeballing this question's Consensus Trend, an interesting inverse correlation with Crude Oil is apparent (negligible WTI/Brent difference). With ISIS's dependency on crude trafficking well documented, their fate in Mosul literally rides on the oil premiums fueling their military assets. Assuming this year's Brent uptrend continues— finishing 2016 at ~ $75—and a crude/consensus delta ratio of ~66, we get consensus probability of ~4% (0.4-((75-51)/66). A quarterly standard deviation of ~$5/bbl around the EOY target puts consensus probability as high as 11% at $70, and <= 0% at $80. This provides a compelling framework for high level players, particularly those more capable of influencing oil prices (than military operations).

For the longest time I sought to evaluate this proposition strictly from the military feasibility standpoint. Then, I moved to the political standpoint. Now, I'm looking at it from the political-economics standpoint. That is, the key factors that will determine the outcome of this event are political, with primarily economic drivers. Thus, since details of these economic factors are generally obscure, I'm reducing my forecast a further (-4) to account for increased uncertainty of these factors. In short, the "hybrid outcome" that is present-day Iraq really did have an "about the oil" aspect all along. This, as much or more so than sectarian divides, is the macro-influence that is conditioning the outcome. After all these years, there is no settlement on oil in Iraq.  (<-- this is not an accident)
http://theconversation.com/iraq-what-happened-to-the-oil-after-the-war-62188 Oil production in Iraq has boomed, yet the people are not enjoying the benefits. Imagine a country with oil production near that of Saudi Arabia but without any of the pre-existing overhead. No thousands of sheiks with mansions in Los Angeles loaded with hookers and cocaine to support. The country should be awash in money! Instead, it has progressed little if at all since its initial invasion. But, that money has got to be going somewhere (out of the country). "The arguments of this study are that political authority in Iraq has fragmented along many axes -- not just Kurdish, Sunni Arab and Shi'a lines -- and that the characteristics of the U.S. state building project have contributed significantly to that fragmentation." Deconstructing Propaganda -- Event Analysis -- More questions than answers The essential background is that there is an intense internal political battle going on in Iraq, with a large number of complications, as to which forces will, and under what circumstances, participate in the attack upon Mosul. The critical piece for this particular story is that the tensions between the Kurds (Peshmerga) and the central Baghdad government have escalated. (That U.S. direct negotiation with the Kurds, by-passing Baghdad, has emboldened the Kurds, and contributed to this rising sectarian tension is a different story.) 1. The "mainstream" narrative.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iraq-oil-attack-idUSKCN10B05F
a. ISIS was responsible ("Amaq news agency, which supports Islamic State, said in a message distributed online that Islamic State fighters had stormed the Bai Hassan facility.") The Bai Hassan facility was the second of the two installations attacked.
b. "shutting down a major oil pumping station" ("which had been pumping 55,000 barrels per day to the northern Kurdish region") 2. First deconstruction
http://www.dw.com/en/five-killed-in-militant-attacks-on-iraqi-energy-facilities/a-19440063
a. No evidence it was ISIS. ("The Amaq news agency, which supports the jihadist group "Islamic State" (IS), mentioned that the assault on Bai Hassan had taken place, but did not attribute it to IS militants.")

3. Second deconstruction
http://www.wsj.com/articles/iraqi-gas-facility-stormed-by-gunmen-1469954013
a. "Output from the field has been shut down since Saturday night, but the reason for this was unclear."
b. "state-owned North Oil Co."
c. "10 miles west of the city of Kirkuk" (an area nominally under control of the Kurds) 4. Third deconstruction
http://www.iraqoilreport.com/news/twin-suicide-assaults-rock-kirkuk-energy-plants-19433/
a. "slashing Kurdistan‘s oil exports by at least a third" Questions
1. If Deutsche Welle is to be believed, ISIS did not claim responsibility for either attack. If it was not ISIS, who was it?
2. Why was the site "shut down" the night immediately preceeding the morning of the attack?
3. Given that state-owned North Oil Co. ran the facilities in a Kurdish controlled area, who controlled the disposition of the oil and who benefited from the revenues?
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-03/kurds-tighten-grip-on-north-iraq-oil-fields-with-kirkuk-deal
http://www.iraqoilreport.com/news/north-oil-company-leader-assassinated-15069/
http://www.iraqoilreport.com/news/new-talks-aim-break-kirkuk-oil-impasse-19380/
4. Was the gas pumped to the northern Kurdish region or exported out of Kurdistan? Summary I believe this event is far more significant that just another run-of-the-mill ISIS bombing. Given the internal political situation, and depending upon who benefited from these oil facilities, I'd say that it would be reasonable to suspect these attacks were either a) a Kurdish signal to Baghdad, or b) a Baghdad signal to Kurdistan; and I'm leaning toward the former. Without knowing more details, it's difficult to interpret the signal. (If pushed for a guess I'd say it was the Kurds lashing out at Baghdad for indicating that the PMUs may be used in Mosul in lieu of the Peshmerga.) In any case, it may be a definite escalation in the internal political battles of Iraq that are not, directly at least, related to ISIS, but between nominally anti-ISIS allies. Potential question resolution difficulty I already anticipate that at some point in the not too distant future, Turkey is going to directly invade Syria. (I believe the coup was faked from the start.) It is also possible that the Kurds unilaterally invade and occupy the eastern half of Mosul, and, separated by the Tigris, the PMUs end up occupying the western half. At that point the battle within Mosul may distract attention away from actually being able to figure out what's going on with ISIS there!

I think we need to consider how the capture of Mosul could play out and which forces could be involved and what each power would gain or lose. Mosul is a big city with a large Shunni population. Capturing Mosul at a cost of many civilian casualties would not be an attractive legacy for Obama, The US will not want to get into the sort of operation that that the Syrian Government, Iran and Russia are involved in in trying to capture Aleppo. I don't think Obama or most Americans would want to see on their TVs the sort of destruction that has happen in Aleppo, being done by US air strikes on Mosul. 
To the north of Mosul are Kurdish Peshmerga forces, to the South are the (Shia) Iraqi government and army, which is unpopular (or hated) by most Sunnis. So even if ISIS is driven out of Mosul the (Sunni) inhabitants are not necessarily going to welcome their "liberation". This would mean likely mean that a post ISIS Mosul would be a de facto (largly) Sunni city occupied by "foreign" (e.g. Shias, Kurds) forces. After 15 years experience I don't think that the old neo-cons idea that "liberated" Iraqis immediately embrace the ideals of western democracy and live in peace and harmony, has many supporters. 
So my conclusion is that for the Kurds, the US (and allies) and the Iraqi government there are more reasons to avoid a blood bath in Mosul than there are reasons to try for a quick victory. 
Why in spite of this I still think there is a chance of Mosul ceasing to be held by ISIS is that non-ISIS Sunnis from within or without Mosul could throw ISIS out. Then the argument might be how Islamic are these Sunnis?

Reducing forecast (-5) on the enthusiastic argument of @RiseToVoteSir ( http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/292538 ) that the Mosul operation will proceed in accordance with the general joint operational planning phases framework, and that the phase which would include the assault of Mosul is not yet operational, and that (I think) weather will prevent this phase from becoming operational within the relevant time period. I'd be silly to not adapt my thinking to a well-considered argument in a situation (such as this) where I have no special insight or access to privileged information. I'm not going anywhere near the forecast of @RiseToVoteSir, however, because I do continue to believe that: a) there is no real "physical" barrier to accomplishment of the mission (only 4421 jihadist fighters), which situation will continue; b) that what will be determinative is a matter of moral commitment to achieve the objective; and c) the local population, including the PMUs, may perceive it to be in their best interest to demonstrate this commitment irrespective of any coalition planning. Mosul is like a block of wood sitting on a table. It's just sitting there, waiting to be knocked over. There is a (psychological) battle bubbling below the surface: Who is in control of the anti-ISIS operations anyway? The coalition or the Iraqi government? The Iraqi government has staked out an objective (before the end of the year), and therefore their future credibility must be, in some way, correlated with the achievement of this objective. I am not as confident as, I perceive @RiseToVoteSir in being, that it is the coalition planning that will determine the outcome. I am of the opinion that the Iraqi's have their own agenda, and that since the taking of Mosul is "as easy as knocking a block of wood off a table," it might be their motivation and commitment that will prevail. Having said this, I do expect a lull as the coalition rotates troops and commands, and some delay as these acclimatize themselves. I also consider the closure of the western approaches to Mosul to be a major factor in eventual mission success, and feel that without definite steps to accomplish this the overall mission would be in jeopardy, but not the specific timing of it perhaps. I'm thinking the coalition has intentionally left the western approaches to Mosul open for use as leverage against the Iraqi government. So, how the issue of "western approaches" is resolved, particularly the timing, will greatly effect my forecast. I'll be looking to really focus my forecast during the September period. How to destabilize an organizational system. $2.1bn pledged for Iraq will go through UN, not Baghdad
http://rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/300720164 Often, when we consider ways to destabilize an organization, we think in terms of breaking existing communication networks or withdrawing resources from the system. Less frequently we think in terms of creating new communication networks or adding resources to the system to INTERFERE with existing command-and-control structures. Assume you are CEO of a large organization. Assume you are following a very basic "incentive-based" control model. In such a situation your ability to control the organization will be generally determined by your ability to control the various incentives provided to drive particular wanted behaviors. With proper distribution of incentives, you can align organizational elements to move the entire organization in a single direction, working as a CO-ORDINATED team to further the agenda that you, as CEO, have determined. Now, assume that some set of outside agencies come in and begin to provide significant incentives to the same entities nominally under your control. These entities are now incentivized to pursue objectives independent, and often in conflict, with the objectives that the organization NEEDS to be accomplished so that the entire CO-ORDINATED system can move forward together. In short, you get various portions of the organization working at cross-purposes, and both the effectiveness and efficiency of the organization suffer (in terms of meeting the objectives that you, as CEO, have set). This is the situation that the Iraqi government faces. When the Western-coalition negotiates independently with the Kurds, they reduce the effectiveness of the Iraqi central government. When the UN comes in with aid that by-passes Baghdad, they destabilize the central government. These efforts, it is plain to see, have the effect of breaking Iraq apart. As CEO you'd like this construction resource A to complete road section X prior to date Y (so as to prepare for the transport of farm product G in growing season K, for example). Nope. Can't do that now. Construction resource A has been "stolen" by NGO M to build something else, and as a result, your entire co-ordinated project series fails.  So, whenever we hear of anything that is "by-passing Baghdad," we should look at it in the light of just one one more thing that weakens the Iraqi central government and contributes to the de-unification (and hence increased sectarianism) of that country. That there is corruption in Baghdad is a separate issue. (The recrimination that Bremer et. al. fostered the creation of the still existing primary channels of corruption with pallet-upon-pallet of U.S. currency isn't relevant either to the specific current question of stability, although it would be to the question of accountability.) There are simple ways that such corruption could be minimized, especially in terms of things like UN dollars. So, historical corruption alone is never an excuse for implementing any new "clean" system. Update: Airstrike in central Mosul kills ten ISIS members

We seem to have two separate movements, with their respective narratives, underway in Iraq. Both relate to the "post-ISIS political future of Mosul," and the second may possibly accelerate the timeframe for the attack on Mosul. The narrative of the first movement is that Sunni's and Shias everywhere, including Iraq, are forever bitter enemies, and there can be no accommodation or peaceful co-existence. More generally, this narrative is applied to all sects, and is therefore used in support of the independent Kurdistan movement as well. This is the mainstream narrative, and seems to be embodied in the recent movements by various Sunnis who demand some independent Sunni "mini-state" within Iraq (with Mosul as it's capital) as the post-ISIS political solution. That this movement is marching ahead is evidenced by the recent parliamentary moves toward constitutional reform which seem to prepare the groundwork for such a semi-independent "Sunnistan." This is the movement that is apparently backed by Saudi Arabia and Qatar, and is apparently silently endorsed by the anti-ISIS Western coalition, as evidenced by both the covert support of the ISIS fighters as well as the management of the pace and scope of anti-ISIS efforts. The narrative of the second movement is that there are nationalistic Iraqis that seek to break free of this sectarian strife, and are seeking to maintain (obtain?) a unified Iraq. This is an alternative (non-mainstream) narrative that does not get a lot of play. But, here is a story that does support this second narrative: "ISIS brutality has created cross-sectarian alliances that will be hard to reverse."
http://nationalinterest.org/feature/iraqs-shia-militias-arent-bad-you-think-16291 Here's an interesting bit: "Iraqi Hashd al-Shaabi [PMUs] to be granted official status"
http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/07/28/477274/Iraq-Popular-Mobilization-Forces-official-status-Prime-Minister-Haider-alAbadi-liberation-Fallujah-Mosul
http://5.160.12.80/en/news/2016/07/28/1142663/iraqi-hashd-al-shaabi-to-be-granted-official-status-pm So, at the same time parliamentary moves are being made to create a framework for a future Sunnistan, the PMUs are being formalized to, presumably, authorize whatever future actions they might undertake. It is possible these two movements will come together, so to speak, in Mosul. If the outcome is to be a Sunnistan with Mosul as its capital, the coalition pace will continue and the battle for Mosul may not start until the political framework for Sunnistan is formalized. If the movement that desires a unified Iraq prevails, Mosul would not be part of any future Sunnistan, and the pace might accelerate with the PMUs taking a more active (and immediate) role in the battle for Mosul. Also, for what it's worth, a major portion of the forthcoming U.S. troop addition is comprised of units of the 18th Field Artillery Regiment.
http://www.fayobserver.com/military/soldiers-from-fort-bragg-deploying-to-fight-isis/article_33c6b7cf-b4cd-5258-8bc4-6146817e0bc2.html Just to date myself, when I hear "artillery" I think howitzer (cannons). Wrong, these guys use High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems (HIMARS).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HIMARS I don't know, I guess to some degree artillery is artillery, and "precision" is way down on the list of required attributes. What I'm trying to say is that when I see those rocket systems I can't help but think "area destruction" (although they are supposedly individually guided?), and it gives me a sense (perhaps mistaken) of the type of battle the U.S. is envisioning. One thing I think is likely: per unit they are more expensive than an artillery shell. "Plans to capture or even encircle Mosul by December are ambitious at best"
http://www.vox.com/2016/7/29/12324640/iraq-isis-mosul-battle This is a great article in that it is the first (ever?) to explicitly state both that: a) Mosul is not yet encircled, and b) that the western approaches is where the gap is. Unfortunately, it does not venture any guesses as to why the encirclement has remained undone or what would be required to complete it.

It took the Iraqi government with US/Coalition support 11 months to recapture Ramadi and Fallujah from the Islamic State. Shaping operations started in July 2015 and decisive operations started in May 2016.  Decisive operations were preceded by at least three months of airstrikes.   The population of Ramadi is estimated at 192,556 and the population of Fallujah is estimated at 275,128 for a total of 467,684 (thanks Wikipedia!).  Mosul has a population of anyone's guess right now but HuffPo says about 700,000 which is at least as good as the 1987 UN estimate that Wikipedia has.  So Mosul is about 1.5 times the size Ramadi and Fallujah together.   The Iraqi Army, with Kurdish and US forces, is not done with shaping operations.  The Iraqi Army is still securing lodgments around Mosul and while there have been airstrikes on Mosul there have not been three months of consistent airstrikes OR "858+" sorties (Wikipedia):
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosul_offensive_(2016)  So given the size of Mosul (1.5 bigger than Fallujah and Ramadi) and the baseline that it took the Iraqi Army 11 months to secure Fallujah and Ramadi from start (securing lodgments, shaping with airstrikes) to decisive action (seizing the cities in May 2016), I'd say as initial estimate that we are 12 months from anti-Islamic State forces retaking Mosul (this operation started in March 2016 according to Wikipedia).   It would take until July 2017 if the ground forces and airstrikes used to take Mosul are the same size as that which were used to take Fallujah and Ramadi and if Mosul is no harder or softer a target than Fallujah and Ramadi. I put my initial estimate at 1% but could revise it up if there is way more bombing of Mosul or if the city of Mosul was completely surrounded by troops AND the Iraqi military was dropping leaflets telling civilians to flee the city.

A month or so ago there was a big announcement that the United States would begin a large "cyber warfare" operation in Iraq targeting Mosul. The message, as I understood it, was that civilians in Mosul were to be instructed to resist control by the ISIS fighters. Or, at least I think I recall such an announcement (message). Since then, we have seen at least three incidents of civilian uprisings in Mosul, each of which was quashed by ISIS, with the concomitant deaths of brave civilians. If we re-arrange the sequence in which we learned the following two events, we now discover another fiasco. First, we learned that ISIS was relocating forces and material within Mosul to embed them in civilian areas. ( http://aranews.net/2016/07/isis-relocates-its-strongholds-in-mosul-to-avoid-airstrikes/ ) Second, we learn of the detail of the exact propaganda messages that have been inserted into Mosul ( http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/millions-of-leaflets-urge-mosul-and-sharqat-people-to-avoid-isis-headquarters/ ). If we make the assumption that the propaganda leaflets were dropped in conjunction with a general "information warfare" campaign targeted at Mosul (including the announced "cyberwarfare" aspect), we see that ISIS has done no more than respond to the propaganda leaflets themselves in a very predictable fashion. So, unless I am missing something, the timing of the info op was so poor that it inspired premature uprisings and encouraged relocation of ISIS facilities to locations that are likely to generate higher civilian deaths than they would have otherwise. Someone needs to be held accountable for this. The operation apparently achieved some results, but the results were ill-timed. I read papers, analysis, etc....It is commotion, commotion. Sure, the Iraqis and allies want re-taking of Mosul to happen soon, but I am always driven back to the question...who is doing the fighting? Even if the best Iraqis are doing it, are there enough forces and do they have the deep logistical support? I remain unconvinced. Nevertheless, with all the "commotion" I can't completely discount the outcome within the next 6 months. so, upping my estimate somewhat so I'm not completely off the median (...have to listen to the crowd, you know.). For comparison, I look at Raqqa...isn't that an IFP?....and look at that city... cutting off access roads, isolating blah-blah, making inroads, BUT not yet taking Raqqa back. Mosul is a lot bigger and a lot more complicated. Even if the re-taking of Mosul is one of the highest operational priorities, how does that benefit long-term strategy if the best Iraqi troops are thrown into a killing buzz-saw and end up decimated? If there wasn't some "magic" timeline on a piece of paper pointing to a completion date for re-taking Mosul, then it would be a different battle plan and it would complete in 2017. My guess is there are as many special forces and snipers as we can logistically put in place in the battle space. The question becomes whether driven by a paper deadline or more conservative battle plan for success and have a solid, viable, 1st-line Iraqi force remaining. I'm skeptical, so I may not sufficiently appreciate the 3-d battle space in play. GJO just added an IFP about the date of Mosul dam collapse. Who knows. Obviously there is the factor of inability to pour enough shoring grout into the weakening structure. But also, there is the possibility that ISIS weaponizes its collapse as a last-ditch scorched-earth tactic. If  GJO is asking the question, then I'm assuming background intelligence is raising some bigger red flags of late..though probably based on its its increasing architectural weakness. Again, possibility exists that ISIS weaponizes its collapse.

I'm very familiar with Mosul.  I was stationed there and at Hammam Al-Alil, a city south of Mosul, but north of Qayyarah.  Capturing Qayyarah, while necessary, does not imply that the re-capture of Mosul will be easy.  There are many reasons for this: -The massacre of ISIS fighters fleeing Fallujah will force ISIS fighters to stay and fight. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/06/30/484186665/video-airstrikes-hit-isis-convoy-fleeing-fallujah -Mosul is split by the Tigris with only 5 bridges.  These bridges will all be heavily IED-ed, and they will be contested with mortars, sniper fire and machine gun fire. -Many sections of "Old Town" Mosul are very tight and the streets and alleys do not allow for effective use of combat vehicles.  Maneuver is severely limited in these areas. -The lack of intense city-wide fighting, like in Fallujah means that there are more structurally sound, multi-level buildings to fight from.  It'll be more of an urban and three-dimensional fight.  Mosul also has tunnels which insurgents used against US Forces and which ISIS will use to defend the city.  www.counterpunch.org/2016/06/02/the-battle-for-mosul-the-peshmerga-advances-on-isis-stronghold/ -Mosul has around 2 million inhabitants whereas Fallujah (as of 2011) has only 275k.  Many fled but it's still a huge city.  Fighting among so many people will be slow and deadly, and therefore require lots of medical and humanitarian aid.  In my opinion, the Iraqi Army will be overwhelmed by civilian casualties.  The political consequences will also be severe and could slow progress.
