What will make them try?
The recapture of Ramadi does not indicate an improvement in the capacity of Iraqi ground troops that would be required to retake Mosul. Mosul has been under IS control for longer and IS forces are quite well entrenched in the city. The battle for Tikrit (a city a tenth the size of Mosul) took months in planning and several weeks for anti-IS forces to secure. A failed attempt to retake Mosul could have disastrous effects on the already low morale of the Iraqi army which means they are unlikely to attempt it without a high degree of confidence. In order to attempt it the army would likely need to be able to encircle Mosul to cut off supply lines and be able to dedicate a substantial number of troops implying that the situation elsewhere had stabilized to the extent that it is feasible to divert troops. 
Troops required: The battle of Tikrit involved around 30,000 anti- IS soldiers (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/03/world/middleeast/iraq-tikrit-isis.html?_r=0). Given that the IS presence in Mosul is more established (though arguably weakened by a lack of funds/troop payment), the city is over 10 times as large as Tikrit, it is located deeper in IS territory  making it easier for them to get reinforcements and the central government has been unpopular in the past, Mosul is expected to be a harder fight. As such I am estimating the coalition will not attempt it with less than 60,000 troops. Where to get 60,000 troops?  Information on the training of troops has been hard to find (including the ratio of international/Iraqi trainers to troops required) – due to lack of information we are using U.S. numbers as a base. In 2015, the US claimed to have trained approximately 12,000 troops and volunteers in 9 months with 450 trainers (3 soldiers to 1 trainer per month) (http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/08/training-iraqi-military-barely-defend-150805114501323.html).  At the rate the US trained forces in 2015, to train up to the 60,000 troop level we have set as the base level, it would take the 450 trainers 36 months to train sufficient forces (assuming that already trained troops were included in the overall number). There is also a high-level of absenteeism in Iraqi forces (between 10-20%) so accounting for that, the total number of trained troops would need to be 66,000 (at the lowest end) adding a further 4.5 months. This number does not take into account the fact that there are British/Australian/New Zealand trainers also supporting troop training in Iraq (though at lower numbers) or that the Americans could send reinforcements so we have adjusted this to  24 months (at mininun) to prepare a force for an attack on Mosul. While these numbers are a very broad estimate, the fact that the forces are unlikely to be ready in 2016 is a view announced by the Iraqi Kurdish deputy PM (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-idUSKCN0UU0AO).  Even if you could mobilze and train sufficient forces for an attack on Mosul in 2016 the assault of the city is itself is likely to take several weeks and the preparation to secure the land around it many more months before. The need for coordinated planning from the international coalition for air support and Kurdish forces is also likely to take several months – hard to say how long each segment of this would take but I think 8 months would be ambitious, meaning that troops would need to be trained before April. Why Mosul?
The city of Mosul itself, while important as it is the HQ for IS in Iraq, is arguably not as important as keeping control of the Mosul Dam. In addition, countering IS’s spread into the Anbar province will likely be a higher priority together with containing the southern advance than retaking the city itself. 
Given this, the likelihood of the government attempting to take Mosul is relatively low – I’m thinking approximately 20% chance that they try.  Will they succeed? 
The second element after whether or not they try is if they will succeed. If they try to take Mosul they would only do so with a high degree of confidence (high number of trained troops, Kurdish and international support, already secured more land to the south, be in a position to encircle Mosul) so the success rate is likely to be higher given that all of these elements would likely be in place. Confidence level would probably need to be above 70% - so I’m setting the chance  of success at that level.  Leaving the following formula: 
20% chance that they try to retake the city * 70% chance of success if they do = 14% chance that anti-IS forces will retake Mosul in 2016

Pros: Increase in airstrikes in Jan. 2016 could be leading up to an invasion as it has in other places in ISIS-controlled territory and even in the past in Mosul itself. Rumors are that coalition forces are being reassigned to training duties to help train anti-IS forces for an assault on Mosul.
Cons: Most fighting has been in the north western part of ISIS territory. USA continues policy of "containment" in an attempt to let ISIS die on the vine.

Some very good comments.  My analysis builds on several of them.  
The anti-IS forces can be the Turks, from the north, the Iraqi's from the South, and the Kurds from the east.  The US will not act alone because of previous experience and the political environment.  The timeline is 11 months.
The Iraqi's are preparing to retake Ramadi with US and Ally assistance.  That will significantly lower their chance of meeting the deadline.  I will give them 5% chance of diverting their forces to the North and successfully dislodging a dug-in force.
The Turks are looking more likely to attack IS this year according to Stratfor.  However, they appear to be more concerned with Syria than Iraq and the Iraqi Government warned them to keep out of Iraq when they sent in a small security force.  They would also need to secure a line of communication (LOC) that is rather exposed.  I will give that 5%.
Most likely of the three are the Kurd's desire for Mosul.  They want the city but Iraq will not let them have it as part of their region.  If they try to secure it from IS they are likely to get tepid, if any, support from Baghdad.  Can they do it in 11 months?  Unlikely if the thorough analysis by @vanderMEI is an indicator.  I will give the Kurds 20% and take away 5% for timeline.    The next big question is if the dam will hold out.  It appears to be lacking in maintenance.  But it is in everyone's interest that it holds.  If it becomes a serious problem you may even find it as an area to compromise in.  If it does burst and flood the city then it becomes a question of who retakes it after the waters recede.  The Turks have no more incentive than before, the Iraqi's will have their own problems in Baghdad which again leaves the Kurd's.  There is high ground directly to the west of the city and the IS forces could probably remain closer to the ruins mixed in with the fleeing population.  The question then becomes, who wants a flooded city in need of a new powerplant and infrastructure.  The Kurd's might if they are looking long term.  I will give the Kurd's another 5% for running faster than IS into the muddy plains.  But what if the Kurds deliberately, and clandestinely, blow the dam?  Then they are rid of IS, have a natural barrier between them, and leave Baghdad too busy to object to their takeover.  I will give them 10% for guile and luck.   The final option left is unilateral withdrawal.  They can either leave on their own or be forced to withdraw by conditions.  They will not leave on their own because they are building the caliphate and must have territory to do that.  Additionally, they believe that all the Jihadi's must die in order for the world to end correctly.  So it will take events elsewhere to force them to withdraw.  Could a Turkish attack force them to leave as they consolidate forces.  This is a real possibility if Turkey really attacks deep inside of Syria.  I will allow 10% for that.  None of the other attacks, air or otherwise, are severe enough to warrant a change - yet.   The key factors for moving the chance up or down will be Turkey's intention, the dam's maintenance status, and the Kurd's readiness to commit.

Retaking Ramadi took 7+ months. Iraqi security forces need to secure the Ramadi and Hit to increase the buffer zone around Baghdad and this requires a prominent presence and the painstaking task of clearing out remaining pockets of resistance. First post and a long one. Apologies for that. To resolve this question, it seems to me that one must first understand why Mosul would be a priority target for anti-ISIS forces - of which there are many and of disparate motivation. I understand why we in the west might consider it a priority as we here demand big prizes for big news and political gain. With our European model of war and conquest, cities matter and big cities matter more. For the other players however - those on the scene with their lives, families, clans, and tribes on the line, the motivation is not as clear. Theirs is not an urban world of states and nations. For these folks I think the best way to come to grips with this is to remove the Sikes/Picot nation state borders and view that landscape in its historic ethnographic sense. This is, it seems to me, important as it will be these many and different ethnographic groups who will be tasked with doing the fighting and dying and it’s well worth asking what’s in it for them. If you then decide that Mosul is not the prize we here think it to be it’s an easier task to resolve the question - will Mosul fall if too few local players care enough that it does? Meticulous calculations of battle strategy and tactics may then become moot. Which is good, because no battle plan survives first contact with the enemy.  If you are committed to the Iraqi state as it once was the answer is clear - Mosul is an important priority objective. Some parts of the Iraqi State and surviving institutions would clearly feel this way along with their superpower sponsors. The oil and other revenue sources a large urban area provides matters in this regard. There is also the overarching war against ISIS in its totality, however for all but the western powers, that is a strategic imperative that may be less a motivation at the local level. But who else among the anti-ISIS forces is committed to that nation state cause or the larger war above any other motivation they might have? This is where it gets tricky and the ethnographic model is helpful. The existing Iraqi state, it’s institutions, and its army are for all intents and purposes Shiite, as are the Militias that are semi autonomous and have formed the backbone of the effort to drive ISIS away from the Shiite heartland and its shrines to the south of Baghdad. These folks are hated north of there where Sunni Jaziran Arabs dominate, and who were the victims of these Shiite groups and the reason ISIS was able to “liberate” the area from them so easily. Historically, these Shiite groups have had little interest in these foreign areas and there is little to gain for the tribes and clans that make up the bulk of the Iraqi fighting forces in fighting and dying for this region. There are already problems developing in Ramadi, Haditha, and Fallujha, all heavily Sunni areas along the Euphrates river north west of and a short drive from Baghdad. Shiite forces of any kind holding these near areas may be in for a long and terrible haul but an essential one as they provide the shield which protects vital Shiite shrines like those in Karbala from ISIS attack. I see little strategic imperative for local tribes in stripping these forces for an advance further into the Sunni north, especially an astonishing 400km’s to Mosul. Except for the defense of the Shiite south, there is literally nothing in it for these southern Shiite tribes and clans. They would be a long way from home, in foreign land, and for no strategic gain to them greater than what they have now. The Militias in particular were raised for defense of the shrines in a time of crisis by Grand Ayatollah Sistani, and were never given the task of offense in the service of the corrupt nation state. While Mosul itself is a polyglot, it sits in a historically Sunni area to one side, and Kurd to the other. There is not now or ever has been much if any Shiite influence. Without a committed and driven Shiite force it would be up to the local Kurdish and Sunni tribes to do the dying necessary to oust ISIS on the Ramadi model. Who would that be? I can’t say. But I can say that if the Kurds had designs on Mosul and were able they would have done it before ISIS became entrenched. They may not have the wherewithal but more importantly, they would put themselves in conflict with the Iraqi state who would demand Mosul be returned. The Kurds would have to wrest Mosul from local Sunni extremists and then face down the Shiite state who wants it back. And of course, there are the Turks and Iranians to deal with. There appears to be nothing worth that cost to them at this point. Their best interest would be in consolidating what they have for the inevitable carving of the spoils once the Iraqi state collapses for good. As for the local Sunni’s, a good portion of their clans have been either co-opted by ISIS as a defense against the Shiite state, or at a minimum, cowed into silence. If Mosul were to expel ISIS it would have to be with the active participation of Sunni’s who would rather have the horror of a Shiite return over that of a Sunni extremist occupation. Thus far, there are no signs of anyone making that choice. In summary, there just doesn’t appear to be enough motivation by enough players to fight and die for Mosul. Except for the wreck of the Iraqi nation state and its western backers, no one seems to have much interest in disturbing the status quo at this time or in the foreseeable future. The real battles will continue to be fought 400 kilometers away outside Baghdad where Ramadi is not an end, but just a beginning. 24 points for time, 5 points for a black swan, and 5 points for an ISIS implosion. I’ll deal with and account for the tactical aspects of an assault if and when that develops.

...the push into Ramadi cannot yet be regarded as decisive. First, it took the Iraqi military seven long months — since May 2015 — to make progress into the central neighborhoods of the city. Since the past summer, with the help of the US Air Force, Baghdad has been repeatedly unable to dislodge IS militants. A state military force deploying the latest weapons, operationally supported by the United States with air cover and, reportedly, ground troops, accompanied by Iran’s top military commanders, US-armed tribesmen and led by vengeful sectarian militias has been haphazardly fighting for more than half a year for a mid-size city 100 kilometers (60 miles) from Baghdad that it should not have lost in the first place and which was seized as an afterthought by a nonstate armed group that had already won the prize in Mosul.
Second, since Ramadi has been declared "liberated," IS has stepped up its urban guerrilla tactics with deadly results for the elite Iraqi troops. Observer tribesmen claim that the group still controls a third of the city, and there are reports of neighborhoods with the IS flag flying within a hundred meters of the national troops. In the midst of a devastated city, we are at best looking at a prolonged tit-for-tat phase of factional advance-and-retreat cycles previously witnessed elsewhere, notably in Fallujah. In truth, the price paid by the Iraqi military and the US forces in Ramadi is already too high. The strategy they worked on for the past months is now known to IS, which wasted no time in switching in situ to suicide-attack mode and withdrew its fighters to "stretch the enemy," keeping them in expectation of a possible counterattack. There are already indications of the Iraqi authorities overplaying their hand with statements that IS will be defeated in 2016 and Mosul is next.
Finally, and most revealingly, Ramadi is arguably not that important for IS. The group will only be dealt a blow in Iraq when the city of Mosul is brought back under the control of the central government. Until then, all engagements are de facto sideshows...

Dateline 1-8-16 However much territory the Islamic State lost in Iraq in 2015 -- Pentagon officials say as much as 40 percent has been retaken by Baghdad -- the blasted hulk of Ramadi points to the price of victory. Iraqi counterterrorism forces continue to hack their way through the city, reporting that they have about 80 percent of it under control, but are still being hit by what one U.S. official said are “squad-size” teams of ISIS fighters. And judging by the daily tally of U.S.-led airstrikes on the city in recent days, the fighting is still fierce. On Friday, the Pentagon reported that over the previous 24 hours, its warplanes hit 16 ISIS “fighting positions,” 11 bomb making facilities, three “staging areas,” and multiple other gun emplacements and groups of fighters around the city. It’s quite a list. Once the shooting stops, the Shiite-led government in Baghdad will have to find a way to gain some measure of support from the local Sunni population, while rebuilding the city in what some estimate to be a $10 billion reconstruction project. It’s a problem that only looks to get worse as fights for the densely-packed cities of Fallujah and Mosul loom on the horizon in 2016. I will keep my percentage the same and not lower it. Just a few thoughts to share.   ISIL is fighting a revolution. It has a presence in Iraq, Syria, Libya, Egypt, Afghanistan, Turkey, Yemen, and Nigeria (along with several other countries). The countries actively fighting ISIL are doing so mainly in a tactical manner and in their own interests, without an overarching plan to genuinely defeat ISIL. Trying to reduce financial resources to ISIL through U.N. cooperation is encouraging, but not nearly enough. The recent Sunni/Shia regional differences couldn’t come at a better time for ISIL and something it has been trying to foment since Zarqawi’s time.   ISIL has many resources besides oil to rely on. Because of crime and corruption in many countries, there is still a stream of income it can rely upon to distribute as needed and where needed. Even items like black market cigarettes and other contraband bring in a fair amount of money.    ISIL still has no problem at the moment recruiting replacements. It also has military leaders who have the ability to initiate kinetic activity in many countries at almost any time it chooses. The attack on Haditha will divert attention and resources from any major projects like Mosul. The dam is vital to the area.     Unless and until regional countries cooperate at a much higher level than is currently being shown, I don’t see how a city like Mosul can be divested of ISIL regardless of the criteria or time frame for “being re-taken” is.

The time the battle of Ramadi took to end in a government victory depends on when you start the calendar, but it took months even if you consider the battle staring in earnest in October. Given the distance from Baghdad to Mosul and the logistical problems associated with a long-range campaign, the central role of elite Iraqi forces in Ramadi, the size of Mosul relative to Ramadi, and the possible indifference of the Kurds to the whole enterprise, I doubt if Mosul will fall to anti-ISIS forces in the next year, even given the fuzzy resolution criteria.

Advances by the Kurds in 2015, airstrikes against ISIS targets, and increased organization by Iraqi/Shiite forces will pressure ISIS forces enough to cause them to retreat from Mosul if they wish to hold Raqqa.  Anti-ISIS forces also have a full fighting season with which to accomplish this, and it must be one of their primary goals. I expect them to make a large effort to retake Mosul.
They may bit hold it very long, but I don't think Iraqi forces have the numbers and training to hold it permanently.

"Some of our sponsors prefer questions that are much fuzzier in nature than others.  "Asking questions about military control is incredibly hard, but they are so important. We think the trend toward simpler resolution criteria has made tackling this issue more tractable, particularly with forecasters who are comfortable with higher levels of uncertainty. Our resolution plan is to evaluate all the relevant information and to make an assessment. There will likely be a grey zone period during the course of the battle (if there is one) in which the outcome is unclear. We hope forecasters will be aware of this and will be patient as we evaluate all the evidence.  This is, frankly, an experiment to assess whether GJ is capable of answering these types of questions. Some forecasters will no doubt be uncomfortable with the uncertainty, but we hope that others are willing to weigh in and be patient through the resolution process. It may prove intractable but the topics are important enough that we believe its worth trying.  "I hope that explains the fuzziness on this one. I will still bring up your question to the larger team and let you know if we decide to issue formal guidance.

Let us start with the question. "anti-islamic state forces" could be anything from Iraqi government to the Kurds to Western ground troops even to Assad's army. As this is a partisan war, the best place to start is to look at the map and what happened in the last 12 months. Here the BBC has a neat interactive map:
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-27838034
It is important to note two features:
1. More bombing runs in Iraqi than in Syria and they are concentrated on the Mosul area. 
2. Mosul is the main link into Iraq, yet despite this their financing and power is barely changed in that region.  The re-capture of Ramadi is important but rather sad. It is like a 15 minute drive down the motorway from Baghdag. Even that took 6 months and the Iraqi forces only really got the center. To me it means that the Iraqi's alone would have great difficulties getting up to Mosul, they would need to capture huge patches of land and as few key cities, like the entire Baiji-region. --> Iraqi cannot do it alone. 
To the Irbil/Sinjar front. Here the Kurds are in the lead. Compared to the strong-hold of Mosul with their new US and Russian weapons, the Kurds are heavily out-numbered and out-gunned. Yes, they took back Sinjar, a key outpost, but let's be honest, it was deserted. ISIS will just move goods via Haditha or through the hills (minor roads). --> the Kurds cannot do it alone.
To the main front Kobane and Raqqa. This is a disoriented front. On the one side the Russians are taking out the Assad resistance by air on on the other side allied bombing runs are doing little to subdue the power influence in Raqqa. Who is supposed to lead the way as likely Raqqa should fall before Mosul? Raqqa is the political capital, but Mosul is the economic capital of ISIS. Gold wins wars, so in my opinion Mosul will be more difficult than Raqqa, meaning Raqqa must fall first. However, there are little ground forces able or capable of doing so. --> Northern Syria will not be re-captured anytime soon. 
This brings my to the essence of the question: Without a Western-led (hence US-led, as the French are hopeless in war) offensive with significant ground forces, Mosul will not fall, especially not within 12 months. So, one must pose the difficult question: what is the likelihood of NATO or the UN sending in a full functional army into Syria and Iraq? In essence a full-scale war. One must ask the rude question "what's in it for me"? Reduction of terrorists activity and lowering the wave of immigrants might not be solved this way, so there has to be a huge economic benefit. At 35-40$/bbl of oil, I somehow doubt that we (The West) truly see one. There is no rush, and since the GJOpen question is time related, let us focus on that key element. 
Gulf War I (i.e. the liberation of Kuwait) was resolved within 5 weeks of ground forces deployment, so the affectiveness cannot be questioned, only the time to get all the approvals and personnel in place. Obama is strictly against another Gulf War, meaning the EU nations must lead the way…this will take to long to pass through the regional and international parliaments. I suspect that gathering a non-US led coalition force from Europe that can act shiftily would take way more than 12 months. Bottom-line, wars are not won with air-strikes and the locals on the ground are too weak. A major terrorist attack (+1000 casualties) would truly change the current opinions and motivation. Likelihood is dropping though. 
So: 4 major hurdles hurdles and a major mood change, let's compound them: 1*2*3*4*5 = 120 / 100 = 1,2% chance. Add an optimistic correction and GJOpen adjustment and the Turkish joker = 6%

Working against a 2016 recapture of Mosul: The recent retaking of Ramadi by ISF and Peshmerga forces took roughly three months <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Ramadi_(2015%E2%80%93present)>, which I will set as a minimum lower bound for the taking of Mosul unless there is a significant increase in international involvement. The actual time it will take to retake Mosul will likely be longer than that required to retake Ramadi, given Mosul's importance and IS investment in retaining (and with more time in control of Mosul, they have more time to reinforce their position). So, the longer a full assault is delayed, the lower the odds of anti-IS forces retaking Mosul in 2016; I should regularly reduce the odds as the year goes by, ceteris parabus. Additionally, Iraqi generals seem to be overly optimistic <http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/06/14/an-iraqi-general-s-plan-to-retake-mosul-is-a-fantasy.html> as do some American officials <http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/liberation-mosul-will-within-months-says-john-allen/>. Let's set a reasonable amount of time for retaking Mosul, after efforts begin in earnest, at a 6 month minimum (see US Army Col Warren's comment <http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-mosul-exclusive-idUSKBN0UC0JP20151229> on patience relative to Ramadi). In order to retake Mosul in 2016, those efforts will have to begin by June. Yet Iraqi forces still need to take Fallujah, where they have stalled <http://www.ibtimes.com/iraqi-forces-capture-ramadi-isis-look-toward-fallujah-mosul-2240563>, after which they will need to regroup before beginning the assault on Mosul. If everything went absolutely perfectly, Mosul might be retaken in December 2016. Perfection is very unlikely, as is the probability of Iraq retaking Mosul before 2017.

On the plus side, the forces in Ramadi are alleged to be excluding the Shiite militias that have caused so much harm with their history of ethnic cleansing of Sunni civilians. However, given the multiethnic nature of Mosul before the arrival of Daesh/ISIS, it may be harder to exclude them. There are several reasons it is less likely that the Iraqi army will be able to retake Mosul before Jan 1, 2017. 
1. Ramadi is closer to Baghdad and further from Syria and ISIS "heartlands." This means that it would be easier for the Iraqi army to cut supply lines and get its own troops to the area. 
2. Mosul is Sunni. The Iraq army is mostly Shia. The Iraqi defence forces that were supposed to stop ISIS simply threw down their weapons and left when ISIS approached. Similarly, Kurds would not have an easy time taking the city and have no interest in taking areas they can't hold. 
3. Since Pres. Obama is in office through mid-January 2018, even if a hawk is elected to the White House, short of a black swan event, it is unlikely that US or other foreign troops will be in the area to re-take the city. 
4. It took months of preparation and fighting to re-take Ramadi, which had a war-time population of around 70k people. Mosul is much, much larger (600k people). Many of these people may not be fans of ISIS but are even less enchanted by the idea of Americans, Kurds or Sunnis in control.  Unless the coalition can somehow convince Sunni tribal leaders to field a massive armed force, it is unlikely Mosul will be taken any time soon. Furthermore, the process of taking such a large, complex and urban city will take immense amounts of preparation and execution.

Islamic State forces are going to find it increasingly difficult to hold territory and stave off forces from the various coalitions acting against them. Many of their leaders are being taken out during air strikes on existing strongholds, which will cause surviving leaders to take refuge in less obvious target areas. Without the demonstrated organisational abilities of these leaders, maintaining a disciplined frontline in their current strongholds will become impossible against larger conventional forces coming into direct conflict in towns like Mosul.

From what I understand, the Iraqi troops who took Ramadi outnumbered the ISIS fighters by over ten to one when the big offensive began about two months ago. If this is correct, taking from October to late December to dislodge ISIS with those odds does not speak well of the Iraqi Army's skill or determination. I also understand that there was significant U.S. help in air power, advice, and engineering during the Ramadi battle. I assume such help will be available at Mosul, but you never know what will happen to affect these things. The other obvious problems are the distance between Iraqi government territory and ISIS territory, that the Iraqi Army would have to secure in order to operate in the area of Mosul, and the whether the government can rely on the Kurds. The cooperation of the Kurds is vital to the operation, and they will drive a hard bargain. The Kurds don't have to take Mosul; they have very little riding on the matter and can be comparatively indifferent if they choose to. So with a year to go, in the absence of any detailed, reliable information, I'll be cautiously optimistic. But as time goes on, that will probably change.

Overall I am quite pessimistic based on the performance of the Iraqi Army to date.  Many of the other commentators have done a good job of analyzing the difficulties the Iraqi Army will have in rapidly shifting from Ramadi to Mosul to take Mosul by 1 Jan.  After they finish Ramadi, which will take a few months more to consolidate, the IA will then have to lick its wounds and prepare for the next operation.  (and everything will slow down for the summer) While they say that the next operation is Mosul, and the US is certainly pressuring them to go for Mosul, they will have a decision point.  There is one strategic factor about this decision point that I have not seen discussed.  The Baghdad government has no incentive to remove threats against the Kurds.  As soon as the Iraqi Army retakes Mosul, then Barzani and the KRG are safe from the ISIL threat, meaning that they then have fewer constraints on "misbehavior" (from Baghdad's perspective): actions that promote KRG independence, just like they were doing before the fall of Mosul.  So why would Baghdad sacrifice Shia blood to remove a threat to the KRG before they have to? So it seems doubtful that they will put a lot of pressure from the top to make the operation happen quickly.  And to make it happen before 1 Jan 17 would require a lot of command pressure to overcome the Iraqi's army's risk aversion, organizational problems, force generation, overcoming losses, etc.
On the other hand, I bumped my prediction back up from a low around 5-10% to account for the non-zero chance of a rapid ISIL collapse (partial or total).  War is the realm of chance after all.  There are numerous indications of the effects of attrition on ISIL.  There are two possible models for this, a rapid "wild fire" collapse or a slow fight to the end.  Their performance to date would favor the attritional slugfest.  However, the complexity of human institutions in violent conflict leads to unpredictable outcomes.  
Another possibility is an ISIL decision to not contest Mosul, which could lead to an earlier far to the IA.  The precedent for this is Tal Abyad, which ISIL chose to not fight for.  Not fighting for Mosul would be a much more momentous decision, however, so I do not think this is a high probability outcome, just possible.

In testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Max Boot, has provides indicators that must occur in order to affect the outcome of the ongoing conflict with Islamic State.  He has indicated that containment should not be the goal but rather defeat.   With the current engagement in Ramadi (Iraq), retaking Mosul will involve a protracted conflict among various military and insurgent actors.  If their is a military victory in Ramadi, their will undoubtedly be an engagement for Mosul.   However, in Boot's testimony he states that  "To defeat the Islamic State, the United States must step up its bombing campaign, allow U.S. joint tactical air controllers to operate on the battlefield, task Special Operations Forces to directly target Islamic State networks, and provide a force of 20,000 to 30,000 in order to galvanize and support a Sunni [anti-Islamic] uprising in Iraq and Syria. "  While this observatio n might indicate a successful outcome for the war against IS, does it provide is with some analytic insight into what might happen in Mosul?  One key indicator would be the military strength of the Iraqi army and the air support provided by the anti-IS coalition.
Momentum is on the side of Iraq and its allies but this is going to be a long, hard slog.  It is not likely to happen within this timeframe.

Main factors
1) Status of supply lines. If the anti-IS coalition can continue to restrict flows of fighters and military/civilian supplies into the city they'll both weaken the IS position and reduce local support, or acceptance, of their presence.
2) IS has had significant time to boobytrap, lay IEDs, dig bunkers and trenches, erect roadblocks and position suicide snipers, which will make wresting full control of the city
3) Aligning the forces necessary to take a city the size of Mosul some time. Given it's location and population, Iranian backed militias will likely not be involved, increasing the need for the Kurdish forces. 
4) Thus, the involvement of the YPG,  Peshmerga, KDP, PKK will likely needed to be sorted which will take some time...
5) As will involvement of foreign troops in terms of who (US, UK, France) and how (airstrikes, advisors, operators, etc.)
6) Determining, in advance, how to manage the outflows of civilians who are trapped and who will remain to control the city All in all, I think it likely that the operation begins before 1 Jan 2017 but highly unlikely the city is clear of all IS elements.

From the Economist; this is not a rosy picture for the Caliphate
"Earlier this year, monitors estimated the caliphate’s GDP at $6 billion. That is a huge sum for a terrorist group, but peanuts for a state of 7m at war. IS’s army consumes over 70% of revenues, according to the IHS report. Foreign fighters are particularly costly, with foreign Arabs being paid at least twice as much as locals and European fighters getting over three times as much. The Mosul windfall was quickly spent, forcing IS to mount fresh raids in search of loot. Waving IS flags and spouting jihadist ideology, Sunnis have chased their Christian neighbours from the prime farmlands of the Nineveh plains—a prize they had long coveted. IS’s destruction of antiquities has bolstered demand for those that remain. Its push towards Aleppo’s industrial zone has yielded a fresh crop of scrap metal. But more recently, with coalition air attacks having checked IS’s advance and oil prices having plummeted, its finances have faltered. Its retreat from Kobani in January 2015 cost it not only access to a key Turkish border crossing, but the big Lafarge cement plant there. This October it lost Baiji, Iraq’s largest oil refinery. American air support for anti-IS rebels now threatens to cut off IS’s last direct access to the Turkish border, hampering its ability to attract new foreign fighters. In early 2015 Abu Saad al-Ansar, an IS leader in Mosul, announced a budget of $2 billion for the year. Monitors now expect it to get half that.
Feeling the strain, IS’s taxes and fines have climbed and grown more arbitrary. Where once governors across its 12 provinces fixed tax rates, now local municipalities do. Scores of imprisoned suspected collaborators have paid upwards of $30,000 to avoid having their heads cut off. Tensions fuelled by pay differentials have degenerated into skirmishes between local and foreign fighters in Tal Afar. Young men no longer attend Friday prayers for fear of being conscripted."

Why the U.S. and Iraq need a Victory in Ramadi - October 14, 2015
A U.S. military spokesman for the anti-Islamic State coalition in Iraq, Col. Steve Warren, announced Tuesday that the Iraqi army is ready to retake the city of Ramadi. According to information leaked to reporters, Iraqi forces have moved to about 14 kilometers (9 miles) from the city's outskirts and an assault against Islamic State positions is likely imminent. Washington is reportedly pushing for the Iraqis to retake the city as quickly as possible. Baghdad and Washington are both in need of a victory against the Islamic State; Washington needs to demonstrate success in the face of growing Russian involvement in the Middle East, and Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's government is beleaguered by a growing protest movement, budget shortfalls and disintegrating ties between Iraq's Shiite, Sunni Arab and Kurdish populations. Sixteen months after Mosul fell to the Islamic State, Iraq remains in a precarious position. Declining oil prices have removed Baghdad's most salient tool — petrodollars — for dealing with competing minority demands. Despite their own oil reserves, the Kurds have been unable to reverse the economic decline that played a part in sending their political climate into disarray.
Baghdad has struggled to regain control of Ramadi since the Islamic State advanced in May 2014, and the group's position in Anbar province has both created and exacerbated tension between Iraq's Sunni Arabs and Baghdad. Sunni Arab tribes have long pushed for formal inclusion in the Iraqi military through the creation of a national guard — something Baghdad has traditionally rejected, often at the behest of Shiite militias and their patrons in Iran. Without greater Sunni Arab participation in the fight against the Islamic State, the Iraqi side of the campaign has largely stalled in recent months; Iranian-backed Shiite elements and the remnants of the Iraqi military have found it difficult to push northward past Salahuddin province. The Islamic State's Iraqi stronghold of Mosul, dangerously close to the southern boundaries of Iraq's oil-rich Kurdish region, has thus remained beyond Iraqi forces' reach. The Kurdish peshmerga, many armed and trained by the United States, have been largely successful in managing their border against Islamic State incursions. However, like Iraq's Sunni Arabs, the peshmerga are uneasy about working with Baghdad. Security concerns, mounting debts and financial shortfalls are taking their toll on Arbil, where a longstanding debate over extending Kurdish President Massoud Barzani's term has devolved into an imbroglio involving the ousting of the reform-minded Gorran coalition from the government. Barzani faces stiff opposition from the Kurdistan Democratic Party's political rivals. Though he is attempting to break out of the impasse by kicking Gorran out of the government and hoping to strike a bargain with the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan and Kurdistan Islamic Union, the move is likely to backfire and create even more room for Iran, which has tight links with Gorran, to push back against Barzani and, by extension, Turkey. Iraq's Shiites are also experiencing internal conflict, including an anti-corruption movement that began in August holding weekly protests to demand reform in Baghdad. Shiite political forces of all stripes are poised to expand their influence in the Iraqi capital as al-Abadi struggles to accommodate competing sectarian and ethnic interests as well as Russian, Iranian, Turkish and Gulf Arab machinations. The Iraqi government announced Oct. 11 that it was sacking plans to issue a debt tender for $6 billion to $7 billion because of excessively high interest payments that Baghdad would be unable to afford. In recent weeks, rumors have emerged of Gulf Arab or even U.S. loans to Baghdad in addition to emergency funding the International Monetary Fund provided earlier in the year. The Iraqi government is in need of a victory, but if previous offensives against Islamist State positions are any indication, the Iraqi army and allied Shiite militias do not have an easy task ahead of them. U.S. pressure on Iraq to press ahead on Ramadi might indicate increased U.S. air and logistical support for the Iraqi army, especially since Washington is re-evaluating its Iraq and anti-Islamic State strategies as Russia lends support to the Syrian government. The United States is also preparing to deliver the second half of a long-delayed shipment of F-16 fighter aircraft to Baghdad as part of Washington's attempts to maintain its own influence in Iraq. The U.S. push for Iraqi troops to retake Ramadi certainly highlights the larger struggle in Iraq and the region as each country attempts to use Iraq's current struggles for its own ambitions. As Tehran works to maintain its patron-client relationship with Baghdad, both Turkey and the Gulf Arab states, led by Saudi Arabia, are looking to strengthen ties with Iraq's Kurdish and Sunni Arab populations. Both Washington and Baghdad will tout a victory against the Islamic State in Ramadi, but the battle's overall impact for Iraq will be minimal. Lower oil prices will persist and challenge the Iraqi economy. Moreover, pushing out jihadist fighters into the western Iraqi deserts or sympathetic tribal communities will not mend the ethnic and sectarian rifts that have plagued the country for generations. Iraq's continued weakness and internal divisions will not only complicate anti-Islamic State operations but also will intensify the regional competition among Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. Situation Report - 12/24/15 -
Iraq's armed forces will move to retake the major northern city of Mosul from the Islamic State once they capture the western city of Ramadi, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said Dec. 25, Reuters reported. Capturing Mosul would deprive the militant group of its biggest population center, a major source of funding and influence. The capture of Ramadi would also give the army a major boost in its move toward Mosul, which the Islamic State took in 2014. The cities are about 420 kilometers (260 miles) apart by road. Iraqi forces started an attack Dec. 22 to dislodge Islamic State militants from the center of Ramadi.

Iraqi forces focused on Ramadi - already taken 2 months. Assuming they first will be ready in April (or later) to focus on Mosul - and will need between 2-6 months to conquer with a likelihood of not succeeding at all.

Mosul is effectively under siege due to restrictions on movement imposed by coalition air power. Recent IS attempts to break out by attacking surrounding Kurdish positions were unsuccessful, this can be seen as a desperate throw of the dice by IS. Current conditions require IS fighters (who are on the whole relatively poorly trained and ill disciplined) to live in underground conditions, with limited mobility, supplies or communications. The effects on morale will be debilitating, leading to clashes between IS foreign fighters and local fighters.
The Kurdish Peshmerga will hold firm against any breakout attempts and  with coalition support deny IS supply from the North and East. Meanwhile the Iraqi forces will build a coalition with Sunni tribal groups, that will lead to the erosion of IS control in areas to the west and south, cutting the remaining supply routes with Raqaa in Syria. An assault on Mosul in April-June 2016 is likely and IS will crumble within two months.
The long term impact of IS occupation (which began covertly as long ago as 2008 but will have been formally exercised for 2 years) will require significant commitment from the Iraqi government to reverse especially when dealing with issues such as child soldiers, traumatised women/family units, UXO and inter communal relations amongst returnees and the resident community.

Here is what I believe to be needed for a successful recapture of Mosul. I have no military experience whatsoever, it just seems like the logical scenario to me: Before government forces march for Mosul, taking the pressure off of Baghdad by removing the threat of ISIS and other anti-government forces in the Anbar province (particularily in Fallujah and Hit) is required. This would allow to free up a large number of troops which are needed for future operations. The battle for Ramadi showed that the government is unwilling to cooperate with uncontrolled ideology-driven Shiia militias prone to war crime (a wise move that will nevertheless slow things down) so troops are very much needed. Also I'd like to note that each city capture so far took around 2 months to execute, these things don't seem to be easy.  After dealing with imminent threats the army could theoretically march straight through the desert and for Mosul but securing Hawija and establishing stable supply lines for a siege that I believe will be a months long, drawn out humanitarian catastrophe could be a smart thing to do beforehand. Taking Al Ba'al or (rather) Tal Afar to the west would cut Mosul and it's surrounding areas from Syria and stop the influx of new ISIS shitheads which also seams to be a not-dumb move and so the operation could hinge on Kurds securing those areas as well. After that we've got a siege of a heavily fortified 1 milion Sunni city conducted by a joint army of Shiite government forces and Kurds.  Trenches are built and minefields set up already and this would be the center of ISIS operations in the whole of Iraq under assault. Ramadi proved that even 400 men can fight off 10.000 troops and slow their advance for two months. Tikrit defended by ~10.000 ISIS fighters required an army three times that size to take and largely ISIS fighters just fled. Here we've got the last stronghold under attack. That's probably the hometown of over a dozen thousand of Iraqi fighters. If they lose, they're finished, I would fight to my death if I were them.  For retaking Mosul I would think that a force of minimum 60.000 (80.000 sounds more reasonable) men would be needed. Also somwhere along the way a reinforced American contingent should be sent to guide bombings and instruct Iraqi troops. Direct involvement of ground troops of any western power (including Turkey) in Iraq is unlikely and I get the impression that the help of Iran and their militias is treated as a last resort kind of thing. Other than just physically encircling the city there are two requirements for the success of the operation. First of all they have to get there. ISIS as a whole must be significantly weakened to make a land offensive effective. Secondly an army large enough for a successful siege must be mustered. The first requirement is best achieved by blowing up oil trucks and pumpjacks in Syria. Weakening ISIS financially destabilises the organisation internally and causes a loss of support as taxes and extortions increas and standards of living fall. Closing the border with Turkey north of Aleppo by the Kurds would be a significant blow to the weapons, foreign fighters and money supply. Another huge setback, though highly unlikely, would be a peace agreement between the Syrian government and rebels. As of the army... It's hard to find any realistic assessment of the present state of the Iraqi military. From the numbers it seems they've got the manpower and equippment, but still http://www.globalfirepower.com/country-military-strength-detail.asp?country_id=iraq ranks them only 112 of 126, roughly on par with Namibia, which has like 10 tanks. The state is very weakened and government forces will have to cooperate with some militias and the fractured Kurdish groups.  I don't think that the defeat of half of ISIS in just one year is very likely, although I'd gladly be wrong. Dateline 12-22-15 The Islamic State may be winning the hearts and minds of people living under its control as these residents grow disillusioned with the military strategies being waged to topple the terror group, according to a rare public opinion poll. Research published by IIACCS, a reputable polling firm in Iraq, shows that support for ISIS among residents living in Mosul, the nation’s second-largest city, has steadily increased since it fell to the terror group 18 months ago. The survey also found that residents’ doubts about the Iraqi Army, and about the aggressive anti-ISIS air campaign led by the United States, are lingering. Nearly 40 percent of people surveyed said ISIS represents their views and interests. That’s up from just 10 percent in June 2014, the month the militants seized control of the city. Around 34 percent of participants said that they now support the Islamic State’s self-declared caliphate and 39 percent would like jihadists to maintain control of Mosul. http://www.vocativ.com/news/263774/isis-is-still-winning-hearts-and-minds-in-iraq/
